description:
Hm. I liked this place but I can't say I ~~loved it.

I ate lunch here on a weekend and there wasn't much going on at the restaurant, so it was quiet and peaceful. The decor of the place is your typical ~~gentrified mission~~~~ with that same vibe. 

The food was pretty good - I had the spaghetti with meatballs (shoutout to Worth It lol) and they were yummy, but I wasn't blown away or anything. The serving size was decent considering the price, it's pretty much what I'd expect eating on Valencia. 

Glad I tried it! But that's about it.
author: Jess L.

description:
My friend and I were looking for an affordable restaurant in the Mission District, specifically an Italian restaurant, preferably with homemade pasta. We found Barzotto on Yelp and learned that it fit all our criteria and was on BuzzFeed WorthIt. That sealed the deal. 

Upon entering, we were expecting to be seated by a waiter, but you actually order up front and then choose a seat. We came early, around 5, so there was no crowd at all. 

Many of the pastas had cheese, and I wanted to order them without it without sacrificing the flavor. I ended up ordering the one pasta that didn't have cheese at all-Little tongues.

Little Tongues (linguine-$16): Delicious! I was so hungry-I finished the entire bowl. I liked how the sauce had a lemony/peppery flavor and a lighter/oil-based consistency. The noodles were perfect and the eggplant and peppers were cooked just right (not crunchy, not mushy). 

Snail Shells (lumache-$12): THIS IS A MUST! Literally one of the best pasta dishes I have ever had. There was sauce inside the large, curved noodles, so with your first bite, the pasta shell pops and the sauce bursts into your mouth. I hate when my pieces of pasta are not covered in sauce, and this dish ensures that you get that sauce:pasta ratio with every bite. I could seriously taste the freshness of this hand-rolled pasta. And the whipped ricotta was so fluffy! Like whipped cream. My friend couldn't finish so she took the rest to-go. You cannot beat the price for this dish-it is SO WORTH IT.

Also, what is up with places charging extra for bread. The focaccia was $4! I always look forward to the bottomless bread service at Italian restaurants-at least all the ones I've been to back home have free bread.

My service experience here was really weird which is why I'm giving Barzotto four stars. I asked the cashier which dish would taste good without cheese and he asked if I was allergic. I said no, I'm just sensitive to it and partially lactose-intolerant, so I can handle a little bit of cheese. He then went on to tell me that they take allergies very seriously and that the only thing I should order is the little tongues. I wanted a different pasta (with the cheese on the side) because they were CHEAPER than this SIXTEEN DOLLAR one. It was like he was trying to get me to order the expensive one! I just went with it. Then, he gave me a buzzer and said to find a table. But I wanted to wait for my friend to finish ordering. I was waiting for her and he again asked me to go sit down. There were plenty of open tables-I didn't need to sit down right away. He said it was so they knew where to deliver the food, but it obviously wasn't going to be ready in the three minutes it took her to order.
author: Megan H.

description:
The drink manu is so friendly that I can easily pick my drink.
Delicious pasta and salad. The beast salad is the best beast salad in the city! Totally out of surprise! 
Five star service! The manager(?) would come and talk with each table.
author: Yantong Z.

description:
My husband and I visited Barzotto on a recent trip to San Francisco, we had the following:

Snail Shell Lumache
Marinara, ricotta, lemon zest & pepper
I've seen this dish all over Instagram and it's what brought me into Barzotto. It was fantastic, the sauce was really bright, the ricotta was creamy and I really liked the extra citrus and zing that the lemon zest added. $12

Extra Long Noodles Spaghetti 
Marinara, pork & turkey meatballs & parmesan 
The meatballs were delicious and juicy, the marinara was the same as the lumache and worked really well on this too. $15

House Made Focaccia 
Fluffy warm bread with more of that delicious marinara $4

After waiting over an hour at Kin Khao the night before, I was afraid we were going to be in the same situation at Barzotto. Fortunately we only had to wait 15 minutes. I love how casual and easy this place was. They have a really great system where you order at the counter, they serve you your food and then if you want anything else you can always order more. The food was fantastic, you can tell everything was made in-house and the staff was friendly. Dinner was also very reasonably priced.
author: Britt C.

description:
I'm tired of places that provide nearly no service yet expect customers to tip like in full-service restaurants. This SF tipping culture has gotten out of control. When did it become the norm to tip for coffee, ice cream, and self-service meals? Barzotto's payment screen strongly suggested a 15%+ tip. 

Aside from unappealing expected tip, the dining experience was lackluster. We sat at the bar at the back of the restaurant and waited for our pasta. His pappardelle came within a couple of minutes. The pasta was half the width of any other pappardelle we've ever had. The dish was good but for $20, it was not inexpensive at all, despite the casual restaurant format. By the time he finished his entire bowl of pappardelle, my radiatore finally arrived. Sitting near the kitchen, we could tell that pasta dishes are not made based on order sequence. Instead, the kitchen waits until several orders of the same pasta are placed so they can make multiple portions in one pan. This led to one dish coming out much later than the other. The pasta I got was overcooked and unpalatable. I couldn't taste anything other than the black pepper. I took a few bites and suddenly lost my appetite.

It was worth a try but I'm not going back.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Was craving some authentic pasta during our SF trip and came across Barzotto. When we got there, it was pretty crowded (Saturday night), so we decided to just do take out. There was five of us and so we decided to just order all the pastas on the list (total of 6 pastas), the wait was probably around 20 ish minutes.

The mushroom one was everyone's favorite.
I also really liked the Spaghetti and meatballs and the Snail Shells with cheese.
Everyone's least favorite was the Little Tongues, wouldn't recommend it.


But all in all, the pastas were authentic Italian pasta and the quality was there. Would recommend :)
author: Katelin N.

description:
This place was featured on Buzzfeed Worth It and won--but the hype is real! My friends and I got 3 different types of pasta and they were all cooked perfectly al dente. I got the snail shells (no snails were harmed in this process) with marinara and ricotta. My friend got the radiators with a soft egg on top and pancetta, and the spaghetti with meatballs.

The snail shells was my favorite out of the three.   ground some pepper in for an extra kick but the sauce was well seasoned on its own. Although if you want more than pasta and sauce you have plenty to pick from, and can customize the base pasta bowl for a couple bucks more. I Portions were hefty, and the entire bowl only cost 12 dollars. I will definitely be back to try some of their appetizer plates.

This beat out Italian Homemade for me as best casual pasta place in the city. For the quality, quantity, ambiance and service -- 5 stars!
author: Rachel L.

description:
I'm so glad my friend introduced me to this place!! It is amazing! It's casual (you order at the front) but the decor is so nice. Pretty dim lighting (a little romantic?). The kitchen open so you can see the chefs preparing your meal if you sit at the bar. 

I've been here multiple times on weekdays for dinner and haven't had to wait :) all the pasta dishes that I've tried here are heavenly, especially the cream sauce ones. You can't go wrong with any of them!!
author: Amanda F.

description:
BARZOTTO has AMAZING pasta, I got the second one on the menu and it was perfectly cheesy with really strong flavours. The pasta was quite soft and I would rate it 4.5/5. The arugula salad was a 3.5/5, it was refreshing and filled with great flavour, but could be better and a bigger portion for the price.

You order your food at the counter and then they will give you a tracker where someone will then bring you your order. There are water glasses and jugs of water that you could take from the side counter, but the glasses did not look extremely clean, so they could do a better job at that. Service was sufficient, and overall, the decor and aesthetics of this place was great. I would highly recommend that pasta and it was great value as well.
author: Alexis W.

description:
I'm a big pasta lover and this restaurant was featured on an episode of Buzzfeed's Worth It (and it won) so naturally it was at the top of my list to visit for dinner during my trip in San Francisco. 

After waiting in line for about 10-15 minutes, it was our turn to get a table, but the hostess said we had to wait for our entire party to be present in order to be seated. We were asked to wait in line, yet again, when our other two friends showed up. We placed our order with the hostess and the payment screen suggested to leave a tip. It's hard to justify leaving a 15%+ tip when you don't know how the service will be like and just the fact that it's not a full-service restaurant.

Moving onto the food - I got the Mixed Lettuces salad and the Snail Shells pasta. The salad had high quality ingredients and was very yummy, everyone wanted some of it! I took a taste of my friend's spaghetti that was cooked very al dente. Both were very delicious, but I much preferred the Snail Shells. The ricotta cheese was definitely what made the pasta mouthwateringly delicious, it would melt into the pasta shells and make me savor each bite. Probably my favorite pasta to date and I don't say that lightly!

The portion sizes were perfect, especially for being $12-$15 each. The ambiance was warm and cozy, very fitting for a pasta restaurant. I will definitely be back at Barzotto for another bowl of Snail Shells on my next trip to San Francisco!
author: Ava A.

description:
This is a lesson why you shouldn't believe everything you see on the internet. 

It's Saturday night and your friends want to go somewhere for dinner in San Francisco. One of your friends was mindlessly scrolling down her Facebook news feed while in class and she saw a video from Buzzfeed. Looks like we're eating pasta today.

From my friend's description the pasta was a one way ticket to flavortown by Guy Fieri himself. It was supposed to taste like a delicious 4 dollar sign restaurant at a 2 dollar sign price. 

In reality the includes a large bowl of pasta freshly pressed, boiled, and served with a variety of different sauces. The pasta is very chewy and delicious, but the sauces aren't as rich as I believed. In particular the ribbon pasta itself is very delicious but the sauce is slightly sour for some reason. There also aren't many other ingredients, so you're stuck eating a bowl of pasta and sauce with maybe a few pieces of meat and mushrooms.
author: Wesley H.

description:
Oh my pastaaaaa.

Barzotto is amazing!!!

For starters, I don't like pasta. I find it bland and boring, not to mention it never makes me feel good (hey, food intolerances of every kind!).

Then Barzotto catered a meal...and I smelled it...and...wow. How could I *not* load up a plate of everything? Sauce and spice are everything when it comes to pasta, and Barzotto has them down to a pat.

I tried every single item, and they all knocked my socks off. Everything was spiced to perfection and gloriously flavourful - from the actual pasta, to chicken, and even some sweet potatoes. The meatballs were also heavenly.

I can't wait to go to their restaurant! (I only wish I could get a big sampler plate; I have no idea how I could pick just one dish.)
author: Nic Z.

description:
Apparently this place was on Buzzfeed's Worth It series. Gotta say, wasn't really worth it.

After a brief hike down to Kirby Cove, we were hit with the predicament of where to go for lunch. A quick suggestion by my friend pointed to this place in the Mission district with a casual mention of hearing of it through the comedic popular food review Youtube series, "Worth It."

There wasn't a line on this hot Sunday at 1pm. Shouldn't have been too surprised. You order up front and then seat yourself. The menu is fairly simple. Each dish is already paired up with its own type of pasta. I thought all the options looked fine, but what really caught my eye was the brunch special that wasn't on the menu: the carbonara, and more specifically the soft egg on top. I'm a sucker for soft eggs, poached eggs, easter eggs, like how could I not choose it when the dish comes with a soft egg while it costs $2 to add one to any other dish.

I don't remember waiting too long for the food. First impression: that's a small bowl. They served all our dishes in bowls. Interesting. But anyway, I popped that sucker open and dug right in. As the yolk slowly oozed out onto my shell like pasta, I could feel the wave of salt crystals rapidly depolarize all the Na channels on my tongue. Like give me two cups of water for that pasta, it was so salty. A bit too much cheese too. I also tried my friend's spaghetti and meatballs, a seemingly innocuous dish. Their meatballs had turkey in it too. It tasted fine, but I didn't think one could mess up spaghetti and meatballs anyway, besides giving a paltry portion--which they did.

When I later perused the Worth It episode on this place, I saw that they featured their spaghetti and meatballs, especially the rough, amazing texture of the noodles. Didn't catch that at all.

Anyway, seems to be a relatively cheap pasta option for SF, but the portions were a bit lacking for me. Definitely not worth the hype.
author: Hanning X.

description:
We came to Barzotto within the first few months of it opening. I was with a group of five, and we all enjoyed the good food in the modern casual environment. 

I ordered Niman Ranch porchetta platter. It was delicious. The pork was juicy and the condiments complimented it perfectly. My friends ordered the pasta, and they all enjoyed theirs. An initial reaction was that the portions were small, but after eating they were all satisfied. The soft serve gelato is also good.
author: Joanna L.

description:
This is by far my new favorite spot for pasta in the city! The restaurant is very casual, and guests pay and order at the front before receiving a number. Once a number is received, guests are able to take a seat at any spot in the restaurant. Usually, bar seating is readily available for small parties of 2-3. 

We decided on the ribbons with short rib and the spaghetti and meatballs. The portions looked small, but they were the perfect amount for one meal. Both were great, but I personally preferred the spaghetti, since I am usually a fan of red sauce. The noodles were both cooked perfectly al dente, and the meatballs and short rib were both flavorful. 

This is a great spot for a casual dine in on a weekday or even on the weekend. The restaurant is quite small, but it definitely has some amazing pasta dishes.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Came here cause of Buzzfeed Worth It!! But I've been wanting to try this place for awhile now.
Parking may be hard to find since it's only street parking. You order your food then find a place to sit. It was quite empty when we arrived on the weekend for lunch. 

Tried the ribbons/pappardelle and it was quite salty... The portion looks small at first but once you dig in and eat, one bowl may be just enough or more than enough! 

The extra long noodles/spaghetti was in Worth It so you know we had to try it! I liked this dish a lot more and I would only come back for the spaghetti. The texture is perfect, just the right amount of chewiness. The ribbons didn't have that texture though. I expected all the pasta there to have that texture but I guess not. 

Overall, it was worth a try but I wouldn't be raving to come back or wait in line for it.
author: Kristie L.

description:
Noooo! Barzotto lost it's touch. We had a magical 1st trip and our 2nd trip was lackluster. 

We ordered the roast chicken, pierced noodles /bucatini and spumoni. The roast chicken was salty but it was definitely juicy and tasty but way too salty.

The pierced noodles was too acidic and the clams didn't contribute to anything in the dish, it was lost in the acidity. 

The spumoni is half the serving size from our first trip but for the same price. Now it's served in a water glass. 

I'm taking Barzotto off my recommended list.
author: Rey L.

description:
Got sucked into coming here after watching Buzzfeed Worth It, wanted to see if it was as good as what they said. 

First of all, the restaurant is very small, and they have a unique way of seating guests. Upon arriving, you put your name down, and wait for your name to be called. When your name gets called, you're free to pick your own table. I actually like this concept a lot. Many times when dining out, I get seated at places I'd prefer not to, and I either stick with it throughout my entire meal, or awkwardly ask to change. A Barzotto, I'm free to pick wherever I want to sit. 

The wait wasn't very long, there were a number of people on the waitlist, but surprisingly only about 20 minutes wait. 

But anyways, we came here for the meatballs spaghetti featured in the video. It was good, but nothing super extraordinary or exciting about it. I didn't even care enough to take photos of it. But what blew us away was the roasted half chicken. The skin was nice & crispy but the meat was soooooo tender, juicy and flavorful. Skip the spaghetti, order the chicken.
author: Elle T.

description:
On service and porchetta, it pushes this place to 4 stars for me. I'll note - I came twice in the same month. First with a friend to try it, and second with a tourist because we were in the Mission already. So. It's a good option in this neighborhood. 

The process
Figure out what you want to eat (the menu isn't too big, so it shouldn't be hard). Order and pay at the front. Take a number to an open table. Sit and wait for service. Go get your own water (near the front) if you're thirsty.

The food
Spaghetti and Meatballs: Pretty solid. Nothing too fancy or amazing about it, but it's a solid dish. The meatballs are a blend of meats, so really read it to ensure you like that type of meatball.

Stuffed tubes: probbably could use more salt. The filling was very creamy, but not too flavorful. Pasta was baked, without much sauce. If you're not a sauce person, but like filling, this would be a good choice.

Ribbons: this one was flavorful enough. Almost too salty (on hindsight, if I ordered both the tubes and the ribbons, the mix of the two might work). The short ribs were really nicely done, and I like the thicker pasta ribbons.

Pierced noodles: This one I liked, mostly for the texture. Not sure what happened to the noodles to pierce it, but it collected some of that clam sauce well. 

Porchetta: I know this place is supposed to be known for the pasta, but seriously get the porchetta. Unless it's against your religion or food choices, this is the thing to get. There's a side of salad and pickles to help cut the fat. SO good.

Service here, even though it's not set up to be full service, is great. Yes, you get your own water. But they come by with your food, pick up your plates, and can assist with ordering dessert or something extra if you need it. Which means. TIP THEM, PEOPLE. Either take some extra bills and drop them off at the table, or pre-tip them at the counter. Don't be THAT person. 

I'd come in a table for 2 or 3, as there's not many spaces for a large party. No more than 4, is my recommendation.
author: Lily W.

description:
Delicious food, service, atmosphere, and I love the self-service concept. Between my bf and me, we had the snail shells, beets, and veggie board. Everything was so good. The snail shells are delicious and hot, with dallops of cheese. The veggie board included pickled and roasted veg, and came with a nice aioli and dallop of cheese. The beets side dish was really delicious too-- in fact, it was probably my favorite out of everything. It comes with pistachios. 
I would come back to try another kind of pasta and some other side dishes.
author: Christina W.

description: I love the minimalist, busy yet artisanal vibe of this cozy space. I love watching the chef slice open the freshly cooked porchetta and eagerly ordered one after witnessing such a feat, and it doesn't disappoint! Not a big pork fan usually, but I enjoyed my porchetta board very much! They have a simple and straightforward wine list, everything same price, which makes the decision making so much easier and I appreciate it a lot!
author: Kailin H.

description:
I always appreciate good service! Thank you BARZOTTO for reaching out to us. We appreciated being invited back to try our other items on the menu and be treated with good hospitality. 

This time around we got to try the baby lettuce, ribbon, veggie platter, and the cherry pistachio gelato. 

The baby lettuce was interesting - it was a bit spicy and not something I expected in a salad. The pea, and walnut were very good. Though I'm not sure if I would recommend it to a friend.. 2.5/5 

The ribbon dish was very delicious - creamy and rich. Everything inside the dish was infused with the sauce. The shredded pork was very tender and good. This time around the pasta was not hard. Maybe the other time they were just really busy? I totally recommend this dish! It's normally $20 and the size is small but if you're looking for flavor, you're looking at it!! 4.5

The veggie platter is what surprised me! That thing was actually good - cauliflower, asparagus, mushroom, bell pepper, and celery. The celery and bell pepper was pickled and not overpowering. The asparagus, cauliflower, and mushroom were cooked just right. The garlic dipping sauce and other sauces complimented the dish. I normally wouldn't get this but you should get it if you want to get in some veggies. 5/5 

We finish all of this with the pistachio cherry gelato. I wouldn't necessarily call it gelato. To me it was more like ice cream. The toppings complimented each other very well. The cherry meshed well with the ice cream and balanced it out. Mostly knocking down points for it not being actually gelato. 3.5/5

Overall had a good time coming back. I suggest everyone give this place a shot.
author: Sherluna V.

description:
Disappointing experience.  

Ordered the porchetta, pappardelle (with slow braised beef, mushroom, and parmesan), and bucatini (with clams).  

The pappardelle was fine, but not outstanding.  

We got a few decent bites of the porchetta, but the meat was overall way too tough.  

The bucatini completely lacked flavor and was a mess.  

There are way better Italian spots in the city at this price point.  Go elsewhere.
author: Christine A.

description:
Came here with my friend, and the pasta ended up being surprisingly good. It wasn't the best pasta I've had and the flavors and seasoning could have been more interesting, but the quality of the pasta was top notch.

I had the Carbonara, and I thought it was well made. The pasta itself was a little softer than I like (I prefer it more al dente), but it was still very delicious, and tasted like it was freshly made and well prepared. The sauce was tasty as well, and I enjoyed pretty much all of it, from the creaminess, to the well cooked poached egg, to the cheese and pancetta.

I had a taste of my friends spaghetti and it was pretty good as well!

Overall a nice ambiance with good food.
author: Tyler T.

description:
After I watched a YouTube video clip of BuzzFeed's Worth It series not too long ago, I decided to visit this incredible, local Italian restaurant located at the Mission District neighborhood in San Francisco. It's called, "BARZOTTO." BARZOTTO serves the customers of all ages to taste their authentic, natural Italian cuisines from pastas to boards especially salads every 365 days a year! The atmosphere is very laid back and calming as I welcomed there. The concept is pretty basic thanks to their simpler menu that shows classic & contemporary Italian dishes. The interior is very modern and sleek like the marbled tables & indie furnitures inside especially the mini outdoor patio near the front door.

The employees here from counter, servers & cookers are doing a fantastic job for making the customers like me an unbelievable, exceptional friendly service! No cons!

Now onto the food! Today on Saturday afternoon (8/18/2018), I ordered the signature and customers favorite dish, the Extra Long Noodles, Spaghetti. It contains fresh spaghetti pasta made from scratch with Marinara sauce, Parmesan cheese & their homemade pork & turkey meatballs (3 counts). As I ate it, that spaghetti dish tasted flawless and delightful! The pasta of that spaghetti did braised very well after boiling and it's quite eatable to bite without being too harden. The marinara sauce was simply authentic just like homemade thanks to their special ingredients of tomatoes, seasonings & a hint of mint! Finally, their pork & turkey meatballs: wowzers! That's the best meatballs that I've ever eaten in many years! Perfectly cooked without being too raw and pale. The seasonings of these meatballs are spellbound to devour thanks to the combination of ground pork & turkey including seasonings and green garnishes. Overall, not a bad pasta lunch meal at all!

Parking at BARZOTTO can be quite challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking lot if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

To conclude, BARZOTTO is the most incredible & unbelievable local Italian restaurant that I've ever discovered & visited for the first time right here in San Francisco! Perfect for friends, family & co-workers gathering day & night. A well received! My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
*FEATURED ON THE BUZZFEED - WORTH IT SERIES*

Upon arriving at Barzotto, you walk into a cozy restaurant with a casual, hipster ambiance and nice decor. This pasta restaurant hand rolls fresh pasta everyday and you can see the chefs through the glass window!

~ Porchetta - Crispy Crackling Pork Roast: MY FAVORITE ITEM HERE!! First of all, the presentation on this dish was phenomenal. Huge slices of pork roast, charred lemon, two different sauces (one is cherry mostarda; I wasn't sure what the other one was), and some cauliflower. The pork was cooked incredibly well - areas of the pork skin was crispy and the rest of the pork was tender. A piece of porchetta, topped with lemon juice and dipped into either of the sauces creates one amazing flavor profile that YOU HAVE TO TRY!

~ Carbonara: pecorino cheese, soft boiled egg, pancetta, and pepper. Simple ingredients, but delightful to eat.

~ Focaccia: served hot and with tomato sauce. Good, but you can probably skip this.

~ Spaghetti & Meatballs: another classic pasta dish. The spaghetti noodles were chewy, which I really enjoyed. The pork & turkey meatballs were flavorful and constructed perfectly. As someone who's tried to make meatballs before, Barzotto has their meatball recipe perfected (and beats my recipe any day)!

Besides the fact that Barzotto was featured on Buzzfeed, it definitely lives up to the hype and should be on your list of restaurants to try.
author: Henry W.

description:
Like many others, I came here with some friends after watching Barzotto featured on Buzzfeed. 

How it works: 
When you first walk in you order right at the counter and then take a seat. From there, someone will come and bring you your food. 

Food: 
According to the video, they featured their spaghetti and meatballs...so we naturally went along with it. 
--Pro: The pasta had a good flavor, delicious sauce, and good meatballs. 
--Con: The portion is good but the price is kinda high for the size of it. 
Rebuttal: HOWEVER, it is San Francisco so it was completely what I expected...and what you should too. 

Location: 
Right in the heart of the mission district near 16th street BART on Valencia. Also plenty of bike parking (car not recommended...just like the rest of SF). 

Overall: 
Worth the visit if you and a couple of friends want some pasta definitely check this place out.
author: Chris O.

description:
I saw this place featured on Buzzfeed's Worth It video, and of course I was excited to learn that it was actually close enough for me to visit. The shop is super cute inside, it feels homey and kind of intimate to me. It's not a sit down and order type of place, rather you order at the counter when you first walk in and then you find a place to sit w/ a buzzer and you'll be served pretty quickly.

I came for the extra long spaghetti noodles and meatballs, but unfortunately they were out of those noodles at the time. So instead I got the dish with pappardelle (ribbon) noodles instead. All of their noodles are made fresh in-house, and you can really taste the difference! I fell in love with the marinara sauce, but I didn't like the pork & turkey meatballs that much. I think it's just because I'm not a fan of turkey meatballs, but still the dish was really good! I also ordered the Porchetta (roasted pork) board, and it definitely exceeded expectations. It was delicious, crispy, fatty, so good! The pork rind part was the best, the crisp and fat from the pork was just too good. Definitely would recommend it!
author: Kathryn T.

description:
My friend recommended this place after she had seen this restaurant featured in a Buzzfeed video. You order first and then you get seated, so it's pretty casual, which is nice for an early Sunday lunch. It was not crowded when we arrived, which was perfect for a party of 6. You order first then get seated.

I ordered the extra long noodle spaghetti. You can see them making the pasta fresh, which is very cool. The food came out pretty quick! It's a very casual.

The spaghetti was good! I loved the texture of the pasta, it's perfectly al dente and it really is extra long! For someone who's not a huge fan of marinara sauce, I thought the sauce was good! It's not too acidic, which is good. It is flavorful without being overpowering. It comes with 3 meatballs, which were soft, tender, and savory! 

I wish the serving size was a bit larger especially for $15 a bowl. But it was definitely great spaghetti! I want to come back here again and try their other pastas and maybe some of their bread.
author: Nikki P.

description:
For our weekly office lunches, I tend to make it a two part deal. One will be a salad or a soup and the other something meat centric. Last week, I decided to get my main from Barzotto. Our order arrived via Caviar on Friday, May 11th around 12:15pm.

*Porchetta Sandwich: Toasted bun, chili aioli, aged cheddar, and sprouts ($11)
*Seasonal Pickles ($2)

I got the sandwich. It had a good amount of pork and luckily, they put the greens on the side, so they held up when putting together the sandwich. (Sometimes with all the aioli, it can wilt the greens a bit.) The porchetta was nice and savory. Like a meaty bacon. I didn't really get any cheddar flavor, but I only ate the insides of the sandwich, so maybe it stuck to the bun? There was a lot of aioli, so it was hard to tell. One of my coworkers ordered the pickles and I tried some. They had a good acidity and were nice and crunchy. More like giardiniera than just straight pickles.

Great lunch spot. Happy I finally tried Barzotto. Their porchetta sandwich was definitely tasty.
author: Elena N.

description:
Snail Shells - AMAZING!! 

Trendy ambiance, good pasta, order at the counter but not that big of a deal because they bring it to you. 

Price is good for the food quality. 

You can tell all the ingredients are fresh. My pasta was honestly a little too al dente but my boyfriend's spaghetti was perfect.
author: Miranda M.

description:
I'm always nervous about going somewhere that's gone viral online or on TV, but Barzotto put those fears to rest. My hunny and I went for a late lunch and walked in to a busy but not crowded environment. I really like these fast casual restaurants for their high food quality and relaxed atmosphere. 

We ordered two pastas and the porchetta board. The extra long noodles was definitely my favorite. I liked the texture of the ribbons pasta with braised beef, but the flavor of the marinara with the meatballs mixed with the extra long noodles made me wishing I didn't have to share. The crispy skin of the porchetta was on point, especially when paired with their cherry mustard condiment. 

I liked how they had a variety of seating options, with individual tables, high seats, a communal table and seating next to the kitchen so you can watch your pasta being made. Coming for lunch was a treat and I can only imagine how busy the place is for the dinner crowd. 

This can be a great place for both dining alone or with a small group. Order when you walk in, grab your carafe of water and have a seat. They will bring those dishes right out to you and you will love the freshness of these carbs and protein. 

Slurp those noodles up!
author: Maria S.

description:
After seeing this place on a Buzzfeed Worth It! episode, I knew I had to come try out the pasta. Although we didn't order spaghetti and meatballs, which was what drew me here in the first place, both my friend and I were very happy with our dishes. The cannelloni dish was frickin amazing, and although it seemed a little on the small side at first, I definitely underestimated how full I would be after finishing it. The filling was creamy and delicious and the sprouts that served as a garnish were a lovely complement to the pasta. The campanelle had a totally different flavor, very aromatic and curry-like. 

I really liked how payment was taken before finding our own seats and receiving our food, and the interior is decorated very crispy, There is no bad spot to sit, whether that's at the counter facing the chefs or at the marble high tables on the side of the restaurant. This place is a gem!
author: Sophia W.

description:
I saw this place on Buzzfeed's Worth It.  With it being in my own back yard, I needed to try this place.  I came by on a Friday and I ordered the spaghetti and meatballs.  I was also really excited about the idea of ordering the porchetta, but unfortunately they were already sold out.  The pasta was delicious and it came together well as a whole.   I don't want to copy what I saw on the Buzzfeed video, but I'd agree that the pasta was less slippery and easier to handle.  Sorry, weird observation.  Oh, and the meatballs were also really tasty.   

In addition to the food, I really liked the set-up and the ambiance.  This place would be considered fast casual in the sense that you order from the counter, get a pager, grab a pitcher of water, and wait at a table for the staff to deliver your food.  This made the restaurants more low key, and a lot of people were in and out relatively quickly.  But, they also offer wine, so this would be a good place to hang out as well.  I'll definitely be back for another bowl of pasta and the porchetta.
author: Mitch T.

description:
Buzzfeed's Worth It called, and the Barzotto meatballs didn't pick up. BECAUSE THEY WERE SO ASHAMED OF THEIR MEDIOCRITY.

The good: 
-high ceilings, general bourgeois ambience, cool bathroom wallpaper, nice staff
-buffalo milk gelato tastes like heavy cream heaven
-juicy and crisp porchetta with pickled veggies
-extra long spaghetti noodles had amazing chew and texture and soaked up the marinara sauce like Lance Armstrong on EPO

The bad:
-curry bell pasta, tasteless with a side of rubbery chicken
-not a ton of seating, and only one long high table for larger groups

The ugly:
- those meatballs...hello tasteless meat sponges of disappointment. However, I doubt even Ina Garten's disappointment would spur the Barzotto Team to take any criticism of these infamous blobs.

Overall, a 2.7 star experience rounded up to 3. But since the Barzotto Team deems it necessary to try to invalidate my experience with their meatballs in the owner comment, this one-time customer will knock the score down to a 2.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Another fast casual (or "fine casual") joint where you pay ahead of time at the counter but get the decor typical of full service restaurants.  My favorite seats are at the pasta bar where you can see the massive amount of artisan effort put into making all the fresh pasta.

Snail Shells: This was purely delicious!  Most fresh pasta I've had is of the stuffed ravioli or floppy pappardelle variety; firm pasta tends to be pre-made in dry form.  These shells probably came out of the extruder earlier in the day; they had the desired firmness you'd expect from dry pasta but also a very unique chewiness that must be because they're fresh.  Very eye opening.  The tomato sauce was delicious of course; ample quantity to get lost in the shell openings.  The big globs of fresh cheese were strange at first, but actually worked quite well when I mixed each glob across 4-5 shells.

Porchetta Sandwich: Roli Roti is stiff competition.  Barzotto did a fine jump standing up.  Not better or worse, just different.  Main difference being that they used a creamy spicy sauce.  It paired quite nicely with the crispy pork.  Definitely a fan.
author: Adam B.

description: Perfect for a quality casual pasta meal in the mission district. There is no wait service - you order at the front & then find a table, we came with a party of 3 on a Saturday night had no problem finding a table. The noddles are by far the Star off the restaurant & the best you will find for the price. The staff was friendly and had such a laid back yet elegant atmosphere. Recommend for dates.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Barzotto is a fun Italian restaurant that's somewhere between fast casual and an actual sit down place. It's decorated really nicely and the price point definitely suggest sit down, but you have to order at the counter and find your own table. 

I came here with a friend on a weekday night and we were able to find a table easily! Between us we shared two bowls of pasta (the beef parpadelle and the special of the day which was some kind of sausage ragu) and the porchetta board. I think the total for this came out to around $70, which I thought was fairly steep considering the portions aren't THAT big. 

The porchetta board was my personal favorite of the meal, and I'm someone who doesn't even like pork belly! The meat paired so well with the cherry mostarda that accompanied it, and the pickled vegetables helped cut through the fattiness of the pork. The skin on the porchetta is also super crispy, almost like a chicharone! 

The two pastas were good but I felt they were lacking just a tinge of flavor. Perhaps with more salt or some red pepper flake it would have stood out more; as it was it was a little bland for me. The portions aren't exactly small, but I would have expected a little more for $20 a bowl considering pasta is so cheap. The pasta texture was amazing though: you could definitely tell it was fresh because the texture was just so chewy and delightful.

Overall, love the idea but I probably won't go again unless someone else really wants to.
author: Melissa H.

description:
overall 3.5 stars but since i can't give half stars, it's a 3. 

u order at the cashier, they give u a buzzer number, u find a table, and they deliver the food to u. it's very simple and quick. i think we were in and out within 30 minutes.

EXTRA LONG NOODLES (4 stars) - loved the al dente spaghetti and tomato sauce. quite fragrant but i had to add pepper and chili oil to really love it. meatballs were soft and delicious as well.

RIBBONS (2 stars) - beef was sort of pulled. i don't think i've ever had this type of beef in a pasta dish. this dish was ok. there was something about it that i wasn't a fan of but i can't quite figure out what it was. pappardelle was good but the sauce was meh.
author: Yan L.

description:
While the food here isn't the best I've ever had, I must say that the amazing natural lighting of the restaurant and the customer service is what makes it stand out to me. With the open kitchen, you have a view of the workers making pasta too which is cool. 

My friends and I came here extremely enthusiastic because we're obsessed with "Worth It."
I was excited to be able to breathe in the same air that Steven had once been in! 

The minute we sat down, we could not stop squirming. We all got the infamous Extra Long Noodles which is red sauce spaghetti with meatballs. We took a thousand photos that alll looked the same (especially high angled) and I think at one point, I even stood up to take a photo. The dish was good and meatballs were juicy. It was nice and light which was exactly what I wanted at the moment. When our porchetta came out, we went crazy taking photos again. We started digging in and couldn't stop raving and nodding at each other "Mmmm, how crispy!" The waitress clearly noticed our energetic spirits because she gave us each a plate of garlic bread on the house. It was so kind of her! 

I would be interested in coming back to try the green colored pasta. Always down for trying unique dishes!
author: Monica C.

description:
Terrible pasta. Superbly underwhelming. Too heavy on the truffle ricotta. Too sweet. No service either as no one bothered to ask how food was.

Went here due to buzzfeed so had high expectations. Italian Homemade Company's so much better.
author: Archan L.

description:
Found this place for our girls brunch by Googling "most instagrammable restaurants in SF" (don't judge me please). We arrived at 11am on Saturday and there were plenty of space to choose from. You order and pay first at the counter and the server brings your food/drinks to your table. 

The space is very airy and pretty, and the manager was taking a good care of us and kept checking if we were ok with everything. I ordered the Radiator pasta dish (mushroom ragu) and it was very tasty. I had to bring the leftovers home with me. Their mimosas are nice and large too! 

I'm not giving five stars for the reason being that they do not offer plant-based milk alternatives. I had latte and the only milk option they had was whole milk. I mean, c'mon, it's 2018, this is San Francisco, lactose-intolerance and veganism is on the rise, so please consider us too in the future. There's tons of options now: oat milk, almond milk, coconut milk, soy milk, cashew milk, walnut milk, rice milk!
author: Kat S.

description:
Fact: There are few bowls of food to be purchased in San Francisco that are as comforting as Barzotto's spaghetti and meatballs.  

Also a miraculous fact: they are decent when delivered. 

Relevant other fact: Pasta is rarely decent when delivered.  

Therefore, fact: I love Barzotto.
author: Archana P.

description:
Saw this place from Buzzfeed's Worth It video, and their pasta does not let you down.

We ordered two things that we saw on the show: the basic spaghetti ($14) and meatballs and the porchetta ($20). 

The spaghetti is al dente pasta made to perfection to the right bite and their sauce is pretty dang tasty. If I had the guts to lick the bowl clean in public, I would've! I'm not a huge fan of the meatballs, but that's personal preference. Wasn't disappointed having it a second time (consistency is good!). It's expensive-ish for a bowl of pasta, but compared to the quality of Olive Garden and The Meatball Bar in Hayes, it's worth it.

The pork loin was good, but isn't as *amazing* as they made it sound on the show. The sauces are really good though, and pair really well with the pork loin. I'm pretty ambivalent about it, my boyfriend loved it.

Pretty dang good food and service overall.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Sunday night Italian dinner anyone? Yes, please!  My boyfriend doesn't really enjoy pasta or Italian food for that matter, but this completely changed his mind!  We first saw BARZOTTO being featured on Buzzfeed's Worth It and it was definitely WORTH IT! We ordered the Carbonara, the Spaghetti, and the Pappardelle for pastas.  We also ordered the Niman Ranch Porchetta board to share.  All of the food was DELICIOUS!  The pasta had the perfect amount of sauce so that the pasta wasn't swimming in it and it was so light that it didn't leave you feeling heavy and groggy.  The Porchetta was the winner for my boyfriend because the meat was juicy and tender and the skin was nice and crispy.  The board came out a little later than anticipated (we didn't mind), but they graciously gave us a complimentary gelato.  We chose the honey and sea salt and it was a party in my mouth.  The sea salt was the perfect balance to the sweetness of the soft serve gelato and the honey.  We immediately started messaging all of our friends to check out this place.  I think we found our new favorite Italian restaurant!  BARZOTTO, we will be back very soon!

Extra Tips:
- It is a type of quick service restaurant.  You order at the register right when you walk in the door.  I would suggest looking at the other reviews, the pictures, and the menu prior to going because it can be a tad overwhelming when you are trying to decide on your meal while there is a line out the door waiting for you to order.  
- The seating is limited.  We went at 6 pm on Sunday evening and it was easy for the 3 of us to sit, but as we were leaving, the place was pretty full with limited tables.  It may not be the best option for a large group if you all want to sit together.  
- The service is great!  Everyone was friendly and greeted us with a smile!
author: Lynne T.

description: It was my first time here! I got the Tubes pasta, it was pretty good however it was dryer than expected, still great! Great spot for dates and hanging with friends. Its also a beautiful open restaurant.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
This is a cute casual place to grab a bite to go! 

The Parpadelle with slow braised beef was just amazing! The Foccacia Bread was so yummy. I only wish that their balsamic was better quality. 

The Chicken was good, nothing fancy. The Spaghetti and Meatballs were okay. The Mixed Green Salad with cara cara oranges was delish! 

I would definitely return for a quick bite or for a to-go order.
author: Caro S.

description: Pastas are great and so is the pork loin. I do like the kind of fast casual vibe where you order at the counter and they bring the food out to you.
author: Sophia L.

description:
2 stars for the ambience, nice staff & that they actually served gluten free pasta. Food was frankly abysmal. Honestly just eat elsewhere ... I had the bucatini (gf) and it was an oily, flavorless mess. They also chopped up the gf spaghetti (wtf). My partner had the pappardelle and was also very disappointed. If you're going to spend $20 per plate of pasta you can do much better then here.

Edit: had to drop down to 1 star due to mild food poisoning
Edit #2: Updating my review due to a very positive interaction with the manager of Barzotto where I was assured that my experience was an anomaly.  Will be giving them another try in the near future.
author: Anastasia V.

description:
After being quoted an obscenely long wait time at Beretta, my friend and I walked a block over to this cute, casual restaurant for a quick dinner. 

The first thing I learned upon entering is that you should order at the counter first, then take your number to your table. That was pretty confusing at first, and judging from the other reviews here, that's not made very clear to everyone. 

My friend ordered the spaghetti and meatballs, and I ordered the radiators, which was radiatore with mushroom ragu, parmesan, and breadcrumbs. 

I try and give restaurants the benefit of the doubt, but honestly as a customer, one of my pet peeves is when the party's food isn't brought out at the same time. Especially when it's just two of you, and one person's food comes out way earlier than the other's. You're left in this awkward position of trying to make the other person feel like it's okay for them to start, and the other person insisting they don't mind waiting. This happened to me and my friend, where my radiatore came probably 15 or more minutes before her spaghetti and meatballs. I know it was longer than usual because we had a lot of awkward pauses in our convo wondering where her food was.

When both our dishes finally came, I thought the pasta was decent, but nothing to get too excited about. If I lived in the area (which I do not), I'd treat this as a convenient grab-and-go place or lunch spot. The serving sizes are a tad smaller and priced a bit lower, giving you the impression it's a more casual spot.
author: Alyssa T.

description:
The food was good but it was way too expensive for cafe style. Anyone who goes back here is a sucker! You got me once, won't get me again.
$100 for dinner for two. Ordered at the counter and it asks for tip before you even sit down. Tip for what? No service!
author: Mike H.

description:
The main reason we found out about and tried BARZOTTO is BuzzFeed's Worth It haha..

I had the snail shells pasta ($12) and I liked it! The marinara sauce had a slightly different flavor from other marinaras plus a touch of lemon zest and pepper, which made the dish more interesting.

My friends all tried the "extra long noodles"/spaghetti ($15) with pork and turkey meatballs, and the overall consensus was that the dish was good but the portion could have been bigger for the price.

I liked the casual system of ordering/paying up front and then getting food delivered to your table.
author: Melissa W.

description: 3.5 - Came here on a recommendation but felt that it didn't live up to the hype. The pasta is fresh made and cooked well - soft, but not mushy. Definitely al dente. I ordered the pasta with pepper, poached egg, and pancetta. It tasted like fancy Mac and cheese, but the cheese sauce was kind of watery, and the egg was super undercooked, with a runny white as well as the yolk. It made for a slightly unpleasant mix with the cheese sauce. My friend ordered the long noodles, which is a standard red sauce with meatballs. It was very tasty and nostalgic, and I would recommend it over the white sauce pasta I ordered. Overall, I would come back if I was close by and seriously craving pasta, but I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to come here.
author: Hali M.

description:
I can't exactly vouch for the pasta at Barzotto since I haven't tried it, but I had a great brunch experience here and would love to come back to try more of their dishes. 

The first thing I noticed about this place was the nice space and ambiance. There's bar seating as well as plenty of tables. We walked in around 1 PM on a Sunday and it wasn't too busy which was nice. 

Ordering food is pretty easy and I like the system they use here. You pay for your food at a Square register and get it served to you wherever you decide to sit. This makes it fairly efficient since you don't have to wait to pay the check after eating. Water is self serve in nice glass bottles, and there are plenty of utensils in tins to go around.

For their brunch menu, they had salads, egg based dishes (made with local cage free eggs!), pasta, boards (veggies, chicken, porchetta), gelato and sides. From my observation here the boards were pretty popular. Whats nice about their pasta is that they can make it gluten free for an extra $2. Prices are around $15-20 which is a little more on the pricier end, but the quality of the food is great. The dishes are deceivingly small, but trust me they pack of ton of food in.

My friend and I sat at a bar seating with an overlook of the kitchen so it was nice to see food being made in front of us.

Two Fried Eggs ($13) - Piccolo farro, mushroom, delicata squash, kale. Though this dish seems pretty simple from the description, I enjoyed it quite a lot and it surpassed my expectations. The eggs were fresh and juicy, and there was a ton of farro to go around. I ended up having to pack a lot of it for leftovers later.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
We were quite excited to try Barzotto after seeing it on "Worth it" and made a special try downtown.

First off, their seating situation is not good. They have a list, but the list doesn't correspond to any particular seats, so the entire affair is disorganized. After we sat down further into the restaurant at a "bar" table (apparently it's fully open seating?) we were asked multiple times by waiters if food coming out was ours. Which would have been wonderful as after ordering it took almost 40 minutes for our spaghetti and meatballs to come out. Which was a complete joke. 

40 minutes for a simple dish of sauce and two meatballs. Are you drunk?

When the food did finally come out (15 minutes after someone ahead of us was served) we found that while we really enjoyed the meatballs the spaghetti tasted like it came out of a box. We'd been so excited that they made pasta fresh - and honestly you either can't tell, or they secretly use boxed pasta during busy times. Either way, the pasta was the weakest point of the dish. I didn't even finish mine it was so bad.

All in all, we wouldn't return. The food wasn't even worth the $14 we paid for it. Definitely not worth it to us.
author: Meg T.

description: Despite the fact that everything is pre made in Barzotto, noodle quality to their home made sauces on their dishes are top notch! I normally dislike heavy pastas with cheese and sauces, but Barzotto has changed my opinion on it. We ordered Snell Shell, Ribbons, and Tubes and unfortunately, all time favorite Porchetta is not available so we ordered Roasted Half Chicken. It turned out to be great too! Noodle is chewy, fresh and yummy :) I am in love with Barzotto, will be back!
author: Jenny N.

description: I have been walking past this restaurant for several years and finally scheduled my time to go. It was amazing. Im not the biggest fan of pasta but the flavors were so well developed. Nothing was overdone, all the flavors went well together. My husband had the spaghetti and meatballs and I had the Papparedelle and beef short ribs. Soooo good. The service was quick too so it was nice not to have to wait a long time for our food. We also shared the Foccaccia which was delightful, the Porchetta which was amazingly flavorful and the gelato. The gelato was the plate that I liked least only because it didnt feel like true gelato more like a really good soft serve. But it was still really tasty. I definitely will be back.
author: MJ L.

description:
I tried the extra long noodles, spaghetti with meatballs, the focaccia, and a glass of the Schiava. I probably wouldn't have ordered the bread if i hadnt seen the reviews saying the portion was small but I thought the portion was just fine for one person. (I did however eat some ice cream before dinner and ate every last bite of spaghetti and most of my bread.) The Schiava wasn't great, and I had a hard time finishing it tbh. The spaghetti and meatballs and bread were pretty average. The service was great though and it didn't take long for my food to come out at all. 

Overall, I'm still happy to return and try something else bc the service was good, it's very conveniently located (super short walk from 24th Mission BART), and there are enough exciting looking menu items. I ate at a two top bar height table by myself but next time I'll likely sit in front of the kitchen area which looked like it would be fun to watch.
author: Lam L.

description:
After seeing this on BuzzFeeds WorthIt I wanted to try it and see if it was worth the hype. I love how unpretentious this place was. You walk up order, grab a seat and they bring the food right to you. 
 
First up was the spaghetti and meatballs some reviewers thought the noodles were too al dente but I thought it was cooked right. I would have loved if the sauce was a little more sweet but it was still flavorful and I was enjoying twirling these long noodles on my fork. Some users were complaining the meat on the meatballs were too soft or bready and I didn't find any issues with the meatballs. They are turkey and pork based so they are going to be on the softer side vs what you would get with a beef meatball. All in all this was an a-ok dish but nothing to write home about or anything that stands out. 

The second dish the Ribbons ~pappardelle with slow braised beef, parmesan and mushroom was so bomb. I enjoyed the pasta on this dish and the aroma that wafted up with each bite was heavenly.  I would definitely order this dish again. 

Another side item I got was the seasonal pickles which was made up of cauliflower, celery and red bell peppers. The flavor reminded me of italian dressing but I really enjoyed this too so I'd order this again. 

I didn't get a chance to try the porchetta but this just gives me an excuse to come back. Portion sizes were a bit on the small side. It was just enough that you're not hungry but not overly full and definitely no leftovers =/
author: Lindsay C.

description: I liked the space.  And atmosphere. But the food was really not great.  I got the beef angus ribbon pasta.  Focaccia bread.  And side beets.   I'm not a food expert or critic. And don't want to bash the restaurant or staff.  But the food was just so not good.  I'd even say it was disgusting.
author: Irvin S.

description:
$20 for porchetta. It came with some good dipping sauces but I was not full. 

My friend got the spaghetti and meatballs and that was hella bland. I seasoned it with more salt and pepper. 

Overall small portions for the price. I yelped El farolito nearby bc I needed one last item to deal my appetite. #damnSFprices

If you are super hungry I recommend eating beforehand because you will barely scratch the surface.
author: Linda N.

description:
Not going to lie - I came here because of the Buzzfeed Worth It episode on spaghetti and meatballs, which ALL THREE of them picked it.

Worth it? Yes!
For the spaghetti and "meat"balls? Nahhhh

Ordered for 4: Porchetta board & 3 pastas (plenty of food!)

Porchetta was tasty, with thanks to the accoutrements. Not as crispy as I had hoped.

Star pasta: Snail Shells, Lumache -- perfect balance of all the ingredients, fresh and bouncy pasty! (marinara, ricotta, lemon zest)

Runner-up: Papardelle  w/ slow braised beef -- again a home run on the homemade pasta! Fresh and perfect texture, tender beef and flavourful sauce perfectly coating every strand.

Disappointment: The Spaghetti and Meatballs! :( Spaghetti was too al dente for our liking and the meatballs were mostly breading?!?! on the inside?!?! Not saucy enough other, so that the meatballs and spaghetti were both on the dry side.  (honestly I have trust issues with Steven, Andrew or Adam now D:)

Spaghetti ASIDE -- everything was delicious, fresh, great prices & great bottle selection too!
author: Lily H.

description:
- Spaghetti with Meatballs (seen on Buzzfeed's Worth It)
- Bucatini with Clams

TASTE (4/5): The spaghetti with meatballs was savory, meaty, and everything you would want in a spaghetti and meatball dish. Came here on a Sunday night and I saw a lot of people that got this same dish too (they only had two pasta dishes available at this time, but part of me thinks other people must've saw that Worth It video too). Noodles had a good firmness and chew to it. Meatballs were excellent. For the Bucatini with Clams, I was not as much of a fan. It had a very vinegar-y taste to it, which was a bit too much for me. It's just an acquired taste that I didn't have.

SERVICE (4/5): Wait wasn't long and after paying, we got to choose our seats. I thought this was pretty effective in cutting time waiting for a waiter to order and get a check. Since the menu is pretty small anyways, it doesn't take a lot of time to choose. And though a lot of items weren't available, the food came out really quickly.

OVERALL: I would come here again for the spaghetti and meatball. It's a solid dish. I would also want to try the porchetta and the desserts. 

(On a side note, I thought it was funny how they raised the pasta dish +$1 preemptively with the release of the Worth It video.)

ALTERNATIVE: The Italian Homemade Company (In Little Italy or Marina)
author: Wendy Y.

description:
In short, its "Just OK".

We came here after seeing it featured on "Worth it" -- though I don't think our expectations were unreasonably high. The spaghetti was pretty generic, and so were the bells. The "bells" pasta had the added aspect of having Moroccan seasoning -- which was interesting, but not very memorable.

The pasta *itself* was pretty good, but the sauces its served in weren't all that special.

While we didn't get one, the "board" options looked like they might be more interesting -- so I'd probably check that out.

On top of this, the portion sizes were pretty small for the prices. I actually prefer a slightly smaller bowl of pasta, so this didn't bother me, but I still left feeling a bit hungry.

As trendy and lively this place felt, I don't think we'll be coming back.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
First things first: I'm not a pasta person. Like at all. I always question why bother eating dough with flavor when you can just have the flavor??? 

Fortunately, I was convinced by the Buzzfeed Worth It video to swing by and see if this place truly has value. I was surprised to see that it wasn't too crowded 11am on a Saturday (when it opened). Though the Brunch menu doesn't list it, they do serve their spaghetti and meatballs. 

The meatballs were unexpectedly light, lots of herb flavors and the meat is very lightly packed into a ball. I liked it! The spaghetti wasn't greasy at all; I thought the marinara was perfectly sweet. 

I don't think the price was worth it ($16 something w tax)- but that's living in the Bay Area for ya. Honestly, it's a cute looking restaurant and they've got other yummy looking dishes to offer, so it's not a total pass. Hopefully I'll get to try the porchetta!

Spaghetti was decent, but if you don't think the price is worth it, you're not missing much. Don't be afraid to try something else.
author: Lilian K.

description:
What a fun new discovery only four blocks from my house! I predict a long and fruitful relationship with this place. 

A friend saw something about their spaghetti on tv so we went there. The meatballs are delicious. I think I had the tagliatelle with beef and could have eaten more because it was so goood. Took two more friends there last night and discovered that most entrees have meat -- which was a challenge since it was a Friday. 

But the house made pasta scored with everyone, especially the cannelloni. The pickled vegetables and beet appetizers were a hit, and we each tried a different glass of wine. High marks for choosing interesting wines -- two from Austria.
author: Tim P.

description:
Do you like lechon?

It's called pork something here but basically it's crispy lechon served with some tasty pickled veggies.

Highly impressed by their homemade braised beef pasta.

Man the flavors we're spot on and the pasta was just melt in your mouth delicious. Forget the Flour and Water hype and come here instead.

It's cheaper and has better flavor and service.

Their spaghetti and meatballs was just average (I had a taste from my friend's dish) but my dishes make me say mamma Mia that's some good pasta and pork!
author: Jack R.

description:
Life is already complicated. Dinner doesn't have to be. 

I love that Barzotto is casual and simple. No need to dress up, no need for reservations, you walk in, order at the counter and seat yourself. They dubbed themselves a pasta bar, but the influences show California ingredients. The menu isn't littered with fancy words and the pasta names maybe in Italian, but the English description is in bold and clearly tells you what you're getting.  Plus, hand made pastas always have a fresher advantage over the dried ones. If you're lucky, on a random Monday night, you can even get a ramen bowl here.

Now, the PORCHETTA with its crispy crackling skin, is always a winner.  I dream about my days growing up in Manila eating lechon with Mang Thomas sauce. At Barzotto, it's a better version that's jazzed up with salsa verde and cherry mostarda or whatever is in season. A small frisee salad is on hand to make your pilates instructor happier.

The exclusively Italian wine selections are straightforward. Do you want sparkling, white, red or rose? light, medium or full bodied? Pricing is $10 a glass or $40 a bottle. That's it! 

After dinner here, you'll walk out with such a full tummy and a newfound serenity, your only problem in life will be choosing the right filter for your selfie on the way to BART. 

Grazie Barzotto, che vediamo!
author: Janice C.

description:
The food is probably 4-4.5 stars.  The spaghetti and the tagliatelle were both tasty dishes and the meat that accompanied both were really good and so were the sauces.

I first heard about this place on "worth it" on youtube.  The prices are not super high, but my issue was that the portions were really small.  If the dishes came with more pasta and more sauce (I didn't even need more meat as I thought the meat portions were not bad) I would definitely bump up my review. For around $43 all said and done, we got two bowls of pasta and didn't leave full.  I'm not saying this place is a rip off, just that I wish it came with more noodles and sauce.

The pasta is made fresh.  I thought the noodles were both cooked perfectly.

I like the idea of casual dining.  You order up front and sit down and wait for the food to be delivered to your table.  Water is self serve.  The place is nice inside, but not too fancy.

I wouldn't avoid going back, but I'm not in a rush to return. I'm glad I tried it and I think it is definitely worth giving a try.
author: Ty C.

description: maybe best pasta I have ever had AND the service was incredible! So kind and attentive. Would come here tomorrow if could
author: Madeline O.

description:
Barzotto has a simple yet unique menu that serves salad, pasta, boards, and gelato. When you walk in, you are greeted at the front where you order first. After ordering and paying, you seat yourself and wait for the staff to bring your food to your table. My boyfriend and I ordered the Extra Long Noodles and Pierced Noodles. I originally wanted the Stuffed Tubes, but the kind chef came to our table to tell us that they are all out of the Stuffed Tubes pasta. We did not pay extra and the chef was kind enough to also give us a basket of focaccia bread while we waited for our order. 

FOCACCIA BREAD: with a side of marinara sauce

Four pieces of hot bread with a side of marinara sauce to dip it in. I tasted delicious herbs like rosemary and thyme with a generous amount of oil and butter to make it crispy. It was super soft in the middle and the marinara sauce cut through the fat to give it a tangy and sweet tomato addition. 

EXTRA LONG NOODLES: Spaghetti and Meatballs 

This dish redefined spaghetti and meatballs for me. The marinara sauce was sweet, tangy, and fresh. I loved how the pasta grabbed onto the sauce so well and it created a more enjoyable experience. The pasta itself was a lot chewier and harder than what I am used to, but I loved it. The meatballs are a combination of pork and turkey and it was just great. It was fatty, flavorful, and worked incredibly well with the sauce and pasta. 

PIERCED NOODLES: Bucatini

I was very surprised with this dish and how delicious it was! The pasta itself was green, which I am unsure how it was made, maybe spinach pasta? Nevertheless, it was amazing! Same pasta texture as the spaghetti so it held onto the buttery and garlicky sauce very well. The clams tasted so good and fresh with a nice briny taste to it too. 

Both pasta dishes had an amazing grip on my fork and I had so much fun twirling it around my fork. Although I thought the portions were small, they really do make amazing pasta dishes.
author: Karen Z.

description:
As I'm sure many others have, we heard about Barzotto from Buzzfeed's Worth It series, and were excited to try a place here in the Bay Area.  We were looking forward to ordering the spaghetti and porchetta (a personal favorite of mine) but unfortunately the porchetta was sold out (we had a late dinner on a Friday night around 9 pm).  Instead, we ordered the bucatini with clams along with the spaghetti and meatballs.

While I wish I could say I loved this place, I didn't have a great experience considering the price, and I'm not certain of the hype around it.  The layout, for one is confusing.  You're first seated, but then have to return to the front desk to order before returning to your table where they'll bring out the food.  It seems like an inefficient process and we weren't informed that we needed to order at the front, so we were waiting aimlessly at our table for about 15 minutes before we caught on.

The food also was not as great as I expected it to be.  I was disappointed to not be able to order the porchetta, which I was most looking forward to, but still had high hopes for the other dishes.  The spaghetti and meatballs were good; the meatballs were tender and the pasta was well cooked at balanced.  However the bucatini left a bit to be desired.  The sauce had capers and I'm guessing lemon juice, which left it briny and acidic.  It was a perfect balance with the clams, however they were left in the shell, making it a nightmare to try to pick out and eat together.  The dish was garnished with furikake, which I found to be a strange combination (I'm not a fan of "fusion" dishes).

Overall while the atmosphere is nice and the dishes are relatively cheap compared to other places in SF, I don't think it's that worth the visit.  You can pay more for a much better pasta experience in the city, and I'd recommend that over Barzotto.
author: Kelsey P.

description: This place is special. Casual but fancy. The pasta is cooked al dente. I recommend the spaghetti and meat balls if you want something rich in flavor. The snail shell pasta was kind of bland but I'm sure a lot of people would enjoy it. The salad is huge so I didn't finish anything besides my rose. Great for a date night or just to chill.
author: Diana L.

description:
We have always wanted to check this place out and finally made it happen yesterday. 

This is a cute little place on Valencia street that hide toward the end of the street closer to 24th so the perk is "Less tourists more locals" yippie. 

I went in at 3PM on a Sunday afternoon therefore wasn't a line or anything but I am sure the line at Barzotto is not as ridiculous as some restaurants in town. 

What I love about this place is: the vibe, the décor, food & service moreover, the option of small/large. Finally I don't have to have doggy bag & didn't overpay for something that I cannot finish. Restaurants should give out an option of half portion for petit people. 

Price range of this place is reasonable from 12$/pasta - $17/pasta. Other dishes are around the same price range. I believe they also have happy hour on week days. 

Definitely a cozy, delicious place to check out.
author: Thao P.

description:
Despite the hype and the crowd, I was a bit let down. I ordered the pappardelle and it was just ok. You can tell the ingredients are fresh, but the dish lacked flavor and the noodles were a bit too al dente. For the price ($20) and the pretty small portion, I think there are better options in SF to satisfy your fresh pasta craving.

The venue itself was casual and clean. You order at the front and then chose a seat at a communal table or bar table top. We were told we couldn't save seats and had to order before seating ourselves. This makes sense, but it is something to consider if you have a larger party during their peak hours.
author: Christine C.

description:
Small intimate restaurant in the mission. I like that you order first and they will bring you your food when it's ready. You can also see people pulling noodles. We came on a Tuesday night so it wasn't too crowded and it didn't get too loud in there. The water is also self serve.

I had the small long noodles (spaghetti and meatballs) and it was roughly around $19 including tip. There were 3 tiny meatballs in there and they were pretty dense and dry and hard to chew through. The noodles were el dente if you're into that. The sauce wasn't too strong in flavor and paired the noodles really well. Overall I felt kinda sad about the price but we are in Valencia after all.
author: Linda K.

description:
I came for dinner around 5:30pm (because of worth it ofc). There was maybe a 2 min wait, but paid up front. We ordered the extra long spaghetti, porchetta and the spritz cocktail, and the total came out to be around $60. The drink was made for u right away and we chose 2 seats in front of the glass kitchen, which was nice to see how the noodles were made. 

Service was pretty quick. We got the spaghetti right away, but waited a bit for the porchetta. The spaghetti was soooooo good. I've never had such an interesting yet addictive pasta before. It's the perfect combination of firm yet soft and tangy. The sauce was also delish. That being said, maybe it's just me, but I wasn't a big fan of the meatballs. They were good, but not to the extent that I think the buzzfeed video made it seem. 

I was also a little disappointed in the portion size of our porchetta. What we received didn't resemble the photos on Yelp at all ;(. The flavor was great, though, and I loved the contrast of the fatty meat with the vinegary vegetables and  spread. 

I liked the spritz, but my friend wasn't a fan.
Haha I also like how they increased the price of both to take advantage of the incoming stream of people ;)

I would definitely come back for the extra long spaghetti!
author: Dee Dee T.

description: Barzotto is awesome- food is delicious, generous pour of wine, and quick! It's on Valencia street, easy walk from Mission area. It's different from other restaurants in that you need to order first at the counter before getting seated. You will have to find your own table but there are quiet a lot of options- counter, communal tables, and smaller 2-4person seating tables. Once you get the number, waiter will bring food over to your table. You can always order and pay more if you want to add something too. Their signature dish is porchetta- crispy, pork roast, and all the pastas are very delicious. My personal favorite is snail shells and long noodles pasta. If you are beets lover, order a side of beets! Dessert is a must. Goat milk based yogurt ice cream is very delicious. They are very quick with orders- I waited no more than 10min for any food. Their one glass wine pour is a lot for the $- almost twice the portion compared to most restaurants. Open kitchen with chill vibes and modern, minimal interior. It's my new favorite restaurant in Mission.
author: Adel A.

description:
I've been here a few times, even used Uber eats for BARZOTTO.

I would say it's simple, but good decent food. Is you're in the mood for some chicken and salad with a side of meet balls or salad this is a good place to try.  Sounds like an interesting mix, but in the end it comes out pretty good

The inside of the restaurant is nice, it's clean and well kept. The music is usually playing some r&b.
author: Raul S.

description:
I love the concept, but in the end, the high price point and long wait-times simply weren't worth it -- especially given that it's a crowded fast-casual restaurant recently hyped by BuzzFeed. We tried the spaghetti meatball, the beef pappardelle and clams linguine - I feel like I could cook every single one of those dishes better at home with ingredients I get from Bi-Rite.

For the same fare, I would go to Delfina and Locanda instead.
author: Ken H.

description: Very underwhelmed and annoyed, I would NOT come back. I don't normally eat a lot and even for me the portion size was WAY to small, it was definitely not worth the price I paid. I ordered the pierced pasta (clams, green garlic) the flavor was OK. There is nothing worse than getting sandy clams, and almost every single clam in the dish was sandy. To top it off, I was served an unopened clam--if a restaurant is going to serve clams they need to make sure to check all the clams are cooked through before serving, furthermore, with such small portions I would hope that everything on my dish was edible. The only thing that made my dining experience somewhat tolerable was the nice ambience.
author: Rene C.

description: Good price. Fast service if not crowded. It's causal dining (order and pay up front) but taste is superb. Large portions in an unpretentious simple bowl. Everything we ordered was good!
author: Gloria T.

description:
Barzotto was featured on an episode of "Worth It" as the cheap price point. As huge fans of Italian and pasta in general, we knew we had to give this place a try given how the guys loved what they were served and how amazing everything looked! 

The menu is small so check it out ahead of time before going to make sure there's something of interest first. Their menu has a range of salads, appetizers, followed by different pasta dishes and wine and desserts. I was told that almost all of the pasta dishes can be made vegetarian if requested, which definitely opens up the options for those that don't eat meat. 

We ordered the spaghetti and meatballs and the snail shells (in marinara) along with a glass of red wine each. Orders are placed at the counter when you walk in, you seat yourself, and then your food is brought out, very very quickly I might add! Given their very small menu and fresh pasta made regularly, the dishes come out very quickly even though it was busy when we were there (around 1 pm on a Saturday).

The food we ordered was absolutely delicious and paired perfectly with the wines we ordered. The sauces were seasoned well and the pasta was cooked just right. Our servings were also a fair size: not large at all but not small. We were left feeling full but not stuffed at all; you could easily get dessert, or share an appetizer. Given the prices, it's a more than fair cost per serving as well.

I agree with the guys in "Worth It", this place was definitely worth checking out and we're going to be more than happy to add Barzotto to our list of regular Italian restaurants!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
If you want delicious and fresh pasta in a hip and trendy setting, Barzotto is the place to go! I've been to Barzotto a couple of times and I am obsessed. The pasta is made in-house...you can't get fresher than that. Every dish I've tried (including my boyfriend's) was mouth-watering delicious. One dish that stood out in particular is Ribbons (slow braised beef, mushroom, and parmesan). The beef is so savory and falls apart in your mouth. I honestly can't wait to go back!

Pro tip: Barzotto is only 2 blocks away from 24th st. Mission Bart! Also, order at the counter.
author: Amanda T.

description:
A friend who had watched Buzzfeed's Worth It had recommended this place to me.
