The chicken was juicy and the side of mustard and aioli that came with it was perfect. There is also a hot chili oil at the table, drizzle that shit on everything. Also, don't leave without trying one of their gelato. Even if you are stuffed from all the pasta, you need to make room for the gelato. Trust.
author: Cindy A.

description:
tldr; there's a lot of hype around this place right now, and I was really excited to try it out. Unfortunately, the pasta that we got was really mushy and moist... and just not tasty at all. I would rather pay a little bit more money to ensure a delicious bowl of pasta than less money for a mediocre one

This place was such a bummer for me. I thought it looked super promising on Yelp, Eater, etc. The SO and I decided to stop by on a Sunday for lunch. Barzotto offers a fast casual pasta concept that is much needed in SF, city of overpriced pasta. You pay at the table, grab a seat, and fresh pasta is delivered to you fairly quickly for a sit down restaurants. Items are priced fairly reasonably (sub $15 for a pasta dish), so compared to other more upscale city options, Barzotto is in a great range for some pretty unique, thoughtfully created pasta options relative to a simple tagliatelle with marinara or something.

Anyways, we ordered the cresta di gallo, strozzapreti, and turkey meatballs. The turkey meatballs came out first and were good, though I guess I'm not a fan of turkey meatballs since the texture makes it a lot mushier and grainier than I would like. That's fine. That wasn't the problem.

The real problem and bummer for me was in the pasta. Both of our pasta dishes were cooked way past al dente. When the pasta itself isn't cooked well, it's hard for the dish to stand out. Each pasta was mushy and moist... not a combo one is looking for in their pasta. In terms of the flavors, while I was intrigued by the cresta di gallo flavors, but the strozzapreti was a real interesting one that didn't work well for me flavor wise. It seemed like the anchovies were crushed and basically baked so the strozzpreti was kind of like a pizza. It was okay to eat, but not particularly standout. Both dishes also looked a bit sloppy, but maybe I'm being unfair since this is supposed to be fast casual. I dunno. 

Overall, I'm just bummed that the pastas were cooked so poorly. Maybe it was because it was the lunch service? Not sure. I might consider coming back if they change their menu, but I think I'm going to wait until they're open a bit longer. Am assuming the mushy pasta was more of an operational problem rather than a technical one.
author: Jasmine X.

description:
My husband traveled allll the way from the Marina (lol jokes) to get to Barzotto and we were NOT disappointed!  It's a cute and charming little spot, where you order first at the counter at the front and then find your own seat afterwards. We chose a bar area that overlooks the sous chefs chopping lots of beautiful yellow cauliflower. 
I ordered a glass of the sparkling Lambrusco (aka sparkling red wine) and I'd say it was one of my favorite glasses of wine I've had in awhile! I loved it!  My husband ordered another glass of red, and then we each got a pasta dish and shared the porchetta.  Hubby ordered the extra long spaghetti with turkey meatballs - the texture and chew factor of those noodles was superb, and I loved the flavor of the turkey meatballs, which is difficult to do with turkey!  I ordered the Snail Shells which was topped with a tasty marinara and fun globs of creamy ricotta!  The porchetta was pretty fantastic - all of the accoutrements along the side were outstanding and the juicy pork perfectly complimented it's crispy exterior!
Finally, we had the local honey and sea salt gelato, which is really just vanilla soft serve gelato topped with lottts of honey and a tad bit of sea salt. I'll be honest and say that vanilla ice cream isn't my favorite to begin with, so that might have affected my opinion here, but this was unfortunately the weaker part of our meal. The gelato was very melty so we had to eat it fast, there was much too much honey, and I was hoping for a bit more flavor in the gelato itself. But otherwise, we thought that the service was fantastic, the pasta was phenomenal and we loved the wine! We would definitely come back!
author: Laura T.

description: Absolutely delicious!!! Must order the porcetta (crispy pork). Worth the trip on Bart. Loved the meatballs and looking forward to going again.
author: Jessica W.

description: Overpriced, pasta that is below the median. Pasta is bland and tastes like kids Mac and cheese. Wines by the glass are good but a touch overpriced. Walk up counter ordering is just obnoxious at this price point. Don't believe any of the five star ratings.
author: M T.

description:
I like the format of this place - you order at the front, pay and get a buzzer, and your pasta will be served to you after you're seated! The pasta is also priced pretty reasonably, around 15-20 dollars per entree. They also have a nice wine and beer selection that you can order, and soft serve dessert if you want something sweet after your meal.

The pasta here is so good. It actually reminded me a bit of pasta that I've had in Italy, which means that it's REALLY good. The portions aren't too big so you still have room for dessert afterwards!
author: Theresa L.

description:
You should get the porchetta board if you dine here. It's a nice serving of meat with a few pickled veggies as accompaniments. The meat was a little bit dry in the middle, but the middle layer was moist and the skin was rightfully crispy.

I also tried the tagliatelle. The mushrooms were the star of this dish, but it was a very small serving.

Prices are a little steep considering portion size.
author: Niki P.

description: I came here with a friend after seeing this place on "Worth it" by Buzzfeed. The pasta itself was good, but for the portion size to price is not worth it for me. I would not pay 15 dollars for it, 10 dollars maybe 12 dollars tops. I got the extra long noodle. I would go back to buy the noodles to cook at home.
author: Aubrey M.

description:
A great find for casual dinner and lunch!

Their pappardelle with slow stewed pork and mushroom is the best pasta I've had recently! Very flavorful and not too salty. The pasta is on the soft side, which I personally like a lot. 

We also ordered porchetta, but oddly i didn't like the crispy skin as it's too tough to cut and chew... but the presentation is unbeatable!

Their exterior is pretty airy and has a refined rustic style. It's a great place for a weekday lunch or even a casual date.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
Came on a Wednesday night around 7:30pm and the restaurant was still pretty busy and about 4-5 people ahead of us in line to order. Environment is very casual and you basically go up to the counter to order, find your own seat, and then you're served at your seat. Restaurant was super dark during dinner so it was kind of hard to even see my food (or maybe we sat at a table with exceptionally low light), and had to shamelessly take pictures with flash :(

The first thing that came out were the meatballs - I'm not a big fan of meatballs, but we ordered them anyway to add some protein to our meal. They were covered in marinara and pretty standard, nothing too special.

The other 2 pastas we ordered were the fazzoletti and the bucatini. Between the two I definitely enjoyed the bucatini more. The reason why I give this restaurant 3 stars is because the pasta didn't have the normal consistency of homemade pasta. As many others have mentioned, it seemed mushy and like something I could buy at a grocery store.

Overall, I give this place only 3 stars because there was nothing extraordinary about the pasta and it didn't even seem homemade. Nothing special about anything we ate and would probably not come back again.
author: Megan K.

description: Had the Radiators with added pancetta, and the Tubes with bolognese. The Radiators had a rich cream sauce, but the Tubes' sauce was pretty unremarkable. Only real compliant is no free bread. While sitting there, saw them produce more to-go orders than they have seats in the restaurant. Will definitely go back to try other options. Corkage is $18.
author: Darren W.

description:
Called to make a reservation but was told it was by walk ins only. When we arrived, there was a line already forming. You have to stand in line to place your order, and then you can find a seat. I stood in line until it was our turn to order and then we found a seat. It was disrespectful how people in the back of the line cut the line and saved a seat before ordering. There was only one lady taking orders so there's bound to be impatient people. It wasn't a pleasant or calm atmosphere during the time of waiting in line and ordering.
My friend ordered the fazzoletti pasta bowl and I ordered the shell pasta bowl. The portions were really small. It felt like they gave me half a box of Annie's shell pasta from their Mac n cheese box. I didn't like my pasta. It wasn't flavorful and the meat was very minimal. I'm a thin girl. I need meat. I love the fazzoletti pasta (Got to try it). The slow braised beef and handkerchief pasta tasted amazing. I just don't like how the portion was so small. 
The bread in the picture isn't complimentary. We had to pay extra for the bread and we only got two bread pieces. 
Overall, it wasn't a good experience eating here. The ambience felt tense, rushed and I could feel the impatience of people in line. I don't like that type of atmosphere.
author: Kristin H.

description: I came here after I watched a review of the restaurant on tv. I ordered the spaghetti and meatballs and it was very good. The noodles have a great texture and are the perfect al dente. The meatballs were well seasoned and proportionate to the meal. The service was fast, especially for Italian. It's a fairly small menu, but the spaghetti was well worth it. I would definitely recommend it!
author: Jill R.

description: Solid spot! I got the pappardelle and it was quite tasty. Wish the portions were a little bigger, but still enjoyed everything nonetheless.
author: Spencer M.

description: We came here with a party of 6, and luckily, there was a spot at the communal table. The style of the place is that you order up front first, and then they bring the food out to you. We ordered the mixed green salad, ribbons, cockscomb, and extra long noodles pasta, and the porchetta board. The portions were just right, considering this was pretty heavy! My favorite was the porchetta, as the skin was super crispy, and I really enjoyed it with the cherry mostarda that came with it. The extra long spaghetti was good too. I think the menu here changes often as well. I'd come back for a quick bite next time.
author: Diana T.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE! I am such a sucker for Italian and was coming to SF for the day. I yelp searched "Italian" in San Francisco and this place was the #1 spot. It was hot and new and once I clicked open the photos I knew I had to come in. The decor is so chic and cute especially with the white marble tables. 

The food itself is as delicious as it looks! I love nice plating of dishes. We ordered the porchetta board, bucatini, cresta di gallo, and little gem salad. All of the dishes were so good! They also make the pasta in front of you if you sit at the hightop area. 

The porchetta board is a roast pork, and I love the sauce that comes with it. The little gem salad was delicious. I loved the bread crumbs on the bucatini and the thick spaghetti noodles. The cresta di gallo was also really good and creamy with cauliflower and the almonds gave it a nice crunch! 

The best part: the prices are super affordable! The total including tip for the 4 dishes split between the 4 of us was $17!!!! Amazing!!!! 

I will definitely be back! A great find!
author: Nicole Y.

description:
Dinner review. 

Fazzoletti - 5/5
Bucatini - 3/5
Turkey meatballs - 4/5
Porchetta board - 3/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: I was very excited to order from Barzotto -- it has a cute and unique menu, and is in my neighborhood (so, assuming I liked it, I could easily go in person in the future).  I'm a big fan of Italian food and it's not often that I encounter a pasta I don't like but I really really didn't like the Lumache -- after a few bites I threw it out.  Will not be ordering from here again.
author: Aisha R.

description: This place was quick and very tasty. I stuck with the classic spaghetti and meatballs and was not disappointed. Also picked up a reasonably priced bottle of wine to have with the meal at the front of the restaurant. The restaurant was clean and staff was very attentive as well. I had a friend that has a gluten allergy, and they were able to accommodate him with GF pasta and chicken (meatballs were not gluten free).
author: Rachel M.

description: Pretty good pastas. Try the spaghetti marinara with meatballs, it's the best! Poached egg doesn't go well with the Spaghetti Marinara; skip that!
author: Goutam S.

description: The most amazing place for affordable and laid back dining! The food is absolutely amazing, fresh, local hand made in house pasta, and the price is crazy good! You cannot get better than this. At least in my experience so far, and I've been to countless restaurants all over SF. This place is pure gold.
author: Bella B.

description:
Disappointed. Everything was salty or over-spiced.  

Bucatini - at some point I could no longer tell if I was tasting chili or just salt. Noodles were inconsistent 
Fazoletti - Rosemary? what rosemary? all I tasted was beef and oil
Giardineria - too sour for me, but I guess it's supposed to taste like that

$43 total including tip.  I'm never coming back.
author: Angelica C.

description:
My favorite fancy casual dine-in restaurant. I love the laid-back atmosphere & city cafe chic decor. Easy to walk-in, order, pick your seat. There were enough people there at 8:30pm Wednesday night for the place to feel lively, and we still plenty of seating to choose from.

The porchetta is AMAZING. Must try. Pair with any pasta and you're good to go.
author: Christina J.

description:
Simply put this was overpriced. 

$20 for the large braised beef and mushroom pasta was absurd. There is more braised beef in 1 $4 taco at tacolicious. And I think I found 4 pieces of mushroom in my pasta. 

When it seems absurd to pay to pay $15 for a burger sometimes, at least that $15 burger satisfies. I'm wasn't satisfied in the least
author: Rich B.

description: Kid-sized portions. The pasta was good but not fancy. You'll be hungry after, so eat a snack before going.
author: Gizz V.

description:
TL;DR - Tasty pasta if you stick with the basics. 

We decided to try this place randomly on a Sunday. 

Pros - quality ingredients, small menu (so what they make is usually pretty good), amazing employees, clean, pretty affordable

Cons - pay first and take a number kinda place (not really for date nights), we ordered the special and the cockscomb and both were kinda greasy (aka, the box was completely covered in oil and actually leaked in the car ride home from having so much oil)

I feel bad for the employees that get so much verbal abuse from customers who don't have any common courtesy and lack the understanding of how to order food. It was really upsetting to see that. I'd come back for the salads.... but I'd be hesitant to get anymore pasta or any of the wines (the wine list was pretty limited).
author: Crystal Z.

description: Ordered delivery from here many times. The food from here is subpar for the prices. The spaghetti I ordered was ok the sauce and the pasta we're really flowery. The pickled vegetables were really bad (tasted off) and I don't understand how anyone can mess up on pickling anything. The seasoned vegetables were bad the best part of them were the mushrooms. And last, but not least the pork dish was decent at best due to it being fairly bland.
author: Jacky C.

description: Pretty great place overall. I would recommend everyone try's some of their pizzas since they were amazing. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and plan on going back here some more. I now understand why it is such a long wait.
author: Joseph B.

description:
Solid spot on Valencia and 24th. Good concept that blends casual dining with the feel of a restaurant. I really like being able to order as soon as I step in the door. 

My friends had the spaghetti and meatballs, and I had the shells with ricotta. Really soft and delicious. We'll be back!
author: Marcel M.

description: Ordered via Uber Eats and 3 of our 6 items were missing. Frustrating how inattentive they are to delivery orders. The food we did receive was good but everyone in my group was left hungry afterwards
author: Ted M.

description:
I'll be honest, my wife and I came here because of Buzzfeed. Will we be coming back? Probably not.
From the minute we walked in, the place does give off a 'busy' impression, but it just seemed down right unorganized instead of busy. 
We weren't greeted and we were waiting in a line that apparently you couldn't be in unless you had already been called by the waiter in charge of the waiting list which I had to track down myself. 
When we finally got to order, at the counter by the way, the people in line behind us kept trying to place their order and wouldn't wait their turn. 

We finally ordered our extra long noodle spaghetti and took our seats. The waiter came up to ask us if we had signed in for the fourth time in the course of ten minutes. 

We had the misfortune of sitting next to a couple and the guy just kept chewing with his mouth open and slurping everything, it was disguising. Granted, this has nothing to do with the actual establishment or food yet.

My wife was served first and it took probably another 10-15 minutes for my food to arrive. 
Don't expect a, "your food will be right out, sorry for the wait," or a "how is everything? Do you need anything else?" It's not going to happen. 
We usually never judge an establishment by solely the customer service experience. We figure, if it's popular and people are eating here, there's a reason. 

Honestly, it's okay. The noodles are good, the sauce and meatballs are good, but it's not what it's hyped up to be. I wasn't impressed. 
On the show, the owner raves about how you aren't able to find another spot in San Fran that serves a $15 bowl of spaghetti, which it true. However, I'm getting $15 worth of spaghetti, you get getting what I paid for.
author: Leilanii L.

description: We visited for brunch on a Saturday while on our vacation in SF. I was excited to go here because I found the concept different, we don't have nothing like this in Miami. The food was good but nothing special either. We had the carbonara pasta, snails shells pasta (was my favorite), eggs Benedict and the house made focaccia which was actually very good the marina sauce that came with it was some good stuff. This is a good place to grab a quick bite.
author: Danisbel C.

description: I'm in love with the papardelle here!! Everytime my boyfriend and I come we have to get this. My only complaint with Barzotto is that it's pretty expensive for the portion size (even the large is kind of small when compared to other italian restaurants). The pasta is always super fresh and cooked perfectly though. Definitely recommend sitting at the bar if you want to watch them making it!
author: Stephany L.

description:
Simple menu, excellent taste! 
I had a salad and the tomato and ricotta pasta and focaccia, Everything was very good. Suggestions for 5 stars... the order and pay concept is ok I understand it but my friend and I forgot to order bread, had to jump back in a rather long line and when it arrived well we were done with our food. A lot of people getting to go orders made for out dine in experience less enjoyable . Some tweaks to how ordering is done could make a world of difference, especially if you are new.
author: J C.

description: My friends and I decided to try this place after watching Buzzfeed's Worth It episode on pasta. I got the Pierced noodles while they both got the Extra long Spaghetti and Meatballs. It was super crowded when we went on a Sunday evening. For $18 I felt like my dish could have been a bit larger since I was left still feeling a little hungry but the flavors were good! My friends liked the spaghetti and meatballs and felt like the portion and flavor profile were spot on. The atmosphere was pleasant and workers were friendly and even recommended which wine to go with our meal. Overall, I would go again if I was in the area.
author: Julie L.

description: Not sure if it was me or I've come on off days but the pastas were way too liquidy. I got the bucatini and the braised beef pasta. I've came here on 3 diff occasions, trying out different pastas and each time it wasn't good. The place is cute, friendly staff but the food was just not up to par. I gave it 3 shots to be fair. After the 3rd time, I realized I won't be returning.
author: Nessa H.

description:
The best item on the menu is the carbonara. It's only served for brunch. So fresh and full of flavor.

Porchetta was ok. Not as good As roli roti.
author: Cindy N.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. Let's start with the people: went in for lunch a few Sundays ago with my husband and our newborn - it's the first time we've been out to a restaurant with our baby and we had the best time.  Rye (manager) and our server (didn't catch his name but he was a younger guy that used to run a few sushi spots) were both friendly, super cool, and took great care of us.  Chatted with them and they just made our afternoon.  Thanks, guys!  Marco, the owner, is a great dude and this is another one of his home runs.  My husband and Marco go way back to RN74 days and we've followed Marco around...wherever he is there is bound to be great food and ambiance. 
The food:  this may sound nuts but I'd drive all the way to SF just for their house foccacia.  Yes, the bread, it's to die for - comes toasted and warm...crunchy perfection on the outside and buttery softness on the inside.  We always order a side of meatballs and it's next level of heaven to dip the bread in the marinara sauce.  Do it.  All the pastas rotate but you pretty much can't go wrong, my favorite is the carbonara with the soft egg...I'm drooling on my keyboard thinking about it's rich creamy perfection.  Wines are approachable and perfect, I love how they divided wines by type and all are $10/glass, $40/bottle, they just make it easy for you.
author: A L.

description:
Although the customer service was great, I really just spent $12 for alfredo sans chicken (Tubes). Meh.  I don't think they know what Cacio e Pepe is. And the focaccia for $4 is two 2x2 pieces of focaccia

&a to clarify, their dish "Tubes" was creamy like Alfredo sauce.  I think the restaurants version is totally different from the traditional Cacio e Pepe.
author: Lady K.

description: I've been here on two separate occasions. I had the fried egg sandwich the first time which was by far my favorite. On toasted ciabatta bread and chili aioli and sprouts, its deliscious!!! I had the eggs benedict the second time, always a classic.
author: Lydia L.

description:
I was a huge fan of Barzotto! I had heard multiple recommendation of this place and finally got a chance to try it recently! I loved the chill atmosphere of the restaurant - it wasn't pretentious or overwhelming. This is the type of restaurant where you order at the counter and then go find a seat and they bring the food out to your table. I thought the restaurant was a great place to have a conversation and just enjoy your dinner - it wasn't too loud and the food was good!

We ordered two small pastas, the focaccia and a bottle of wine for 2. If you're starving, then I would say this is probably enough food for 2 and I would either make one pasta a large or add another starter. For how hungry I was, I thought this was the perfect amount! We went with the Radiators and the Pierced Noodles. I love a good cacio e pepe and this one was fairly good! It was a little on the heavy side for me but the flavors and seasoning were great. The Radiators was a more unique pasta with a lot of tomatoes. Let me just say that I'm not a huge fan of tomatoes but I loved this pasta! It was so light and lemony - I loved the flavors!

Overall, I really enjoyed my experience at Barzotto and will definitely be back again!
author: Malika R.

description:
Left feeling disappointed as it reminds me of an evolved Pasta Pomodoro.  Overpriced for pasta dishes that are over sauced and underwhelming.

Positives are great salads, location and interiors.
author: Maura M.

description: This has got to be the biggest ripoff in town. It's a want-to-be trendy establishment -- with NO table service and a very limited menu. Food was equally below par with zero flavor and overly cooked meat. What a disappointment!
author: Anita L.

description:
Great little place where you order your pastas and dishes at the counter; staff bring them to your table. A "Pasta Bar" if you will. Very chill vibe backed with some fun contemporary and 90s hip-hop and chill electronica at just the right volume for a date night or calm night out with friends.

I've had every dish here now several times. Consistency is excellent, staff is great, and pastas are spot on! No kidding, you just don't need better pasta dishes than this. 

Growing up an Italian kid on the east coast I'd describe the food as somewhere between grandma's Sunday best and a hip Manhattan hole in the wall. I just want to keep going back. 

Note that none of the dishes are over or under seasoned and each dish is brought to life with a clear idea of the flavors and ingredients. Flavors and textures are expressed simply, again like a home cooked meal. Each dish makes you somehow feel warm and comfortable. I noticed some reviewers are underwhelmed by the fact that the dishes aren't "wow" in your face. Home style pasta isn't supposed to do that.

I suggest bringing some friends and going family-style, picking up a small of each pasta dish as well as a side of the beats with ricotta and veal meatballs (don't skip the beats!).  A nice glass of wine and some laughs will go perfect with your meal. Skip the protein dishes (and don't bring any gluten-intolerant friends) for a perfect time.
author: Steve B.

description:
I'd hate to sound like a valley girl but I'm gonna go ahead and do it and say OMG is this NOT the BEST tasting PASTA in the WORLD, like mocha choka latta yah yah ugg boots meta!!!!!  In all seriousness, I did thoroughly enjoy dinner here on a random Monday night with my college friends.  There were about eight of us, so we took up a big table, which is usually communal.  We started off with a couple of bottles of wine, and then moved on to the food.  We ordered just about everything, and everything was good.  I'm talking about everything.  All the pastas had different flavors but were equally delicious.  The Ribbons (pappardelle) was my favorite, though.  For dessert, we tried all of the gelatos.  You can't go wrong with any flavor you choose, but I personally preferred the Rum Raisin Syrup with Candied Walnuts just because anything with alcohol in it tickles my fancy.

The service here was particularly stellar.  I think it was Justin who helped us out.  He would come over to make sure we were enjoying our 15 dishes and bottles of wine.  This place is a good spot for a get together!  If you want to do family style like we did, you can pass dishes around, or if you want to be little grinches and keep your meal to yourself, you can order up at the cashier separately.  So convenient!
author: Annie A.

description: Really, truly terrible. Ordered a salad, spaghetti with meatballs and a campanelle with broccoli rabe. Waited for 45 minutes, the spaghetti never showed up, and the campanelle dish came out tasting like the ingredients were all hastily boiled together upon the staff realizing that they forgot our order. At $70+ for two pastas, a salad and two glasses of wine, I expected better. We bailed before even getting the spaghetti with meatballs and will never be coming back.
author: Annie G.

description:
It is definitely trying to be a Souvla for pasta but it isn't working because of the food. They get a star for service as the staff was nice, helpful, and attentive. And another star for ambience as the place is charming, love the open kitchen, the music was great, and I liked the casualness of the pay upfront style. But that's it unfortunately. 

My partner and I split the little gem salad, Cacio e Pepe pasta, and marina and ricotta pasta. The little gem salad was not little gems. It was chopped up romaine lettuce. The dressing was ok but not very flavorful. 

The Cacio e Pepe was the worst dish. They made a sticky Béchamel sauce and then just ground a tiny bit of pepper on the top. The pasta was a little mushy. 

The marinara and ricotta pasta was like cheap grocery store red sauce with ricotta dollops. The pasta was cooked decently but the noodles were dry and did not taste fresh or homemade. 

It cost $60 with two glasses of wine (the medium Cora Montepulciano D'Abruzzo was really tasty), and it felt like we could have had a better tasting meal with pre-made grocery store ingredients. Too bad because it is a charming spot.
author: Sean M.

description:
Loving the concept! The staff is ultra friendly and helpful. You order at the counter, and then pick your table. However, after your initial order you can bypass the main line by going to a separate register if you would like to get anything else. 

The food was delicious. We had the Snails (lumache) and Ribbons (pappardelle) pastas, with the Cabbage & Kale salad. For dessert the Salted Caramel & Dark Chocolate Gelato Sunday...pure heaven. Their gelato is soft serve and I am dreaming about it as I type.     

My only critique is that the food did not come out altogether, and the salad had to be asked for. It would be great if they could bring out food in the traditional order of starters, then entrees. I'm sure this is a growing pain, as Barzotto is fairly new. 

I will absolutely be back!
author: Erin J.

description:
Meh I don't see what the hype is about. Quite typical Mission place w/ stereotypical gentrified Mission crowd. 

The food: spaghetti was a little tart, sauce lacked dimension and it didn't coat the noodle well enough. Wine was decent portion for a $10 glass but then again you could get a decent bottle for $10 and it'll taste just about the same. 

Nice staff, they're chill, nothing exceptional about service. 

I had a date here & we both thought it was a little underwhelming. We both did not finish our pasta nor salad. Killed the wine though.
author: Andy B.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while since it's down the block from where I live and am SO glad I did. 

It's a small and inviting space. Not a place I'd bring a big group, but it has adequate seating for a small group. The service is warm and personable -- the man who took our order was helpful and also just very nice! 

The little gem salad is delicious and fresh, with an excellent dressing that pairs well with the vegetables. The cocks comb pasta was the standout for me though, with spinach-flavored fresh pasta, cauliflower, chili flakes and almonds dressed in olive oil. This unique combination of things that came together really well, and was light yet satisfying. My friend had the pappardelle which was also excellent, with a rich and comforting sauce. 

Portion sizes are on point, not too big or too small, and prices are great for the quality of the food. The wine list is accessible also -- I hate when I go to restaurants that have indecipherable obscure wines on the menu but Barzotto pulls off the "Italian wines that you might not be super familiar with" thing really well by making the selection small and price reasonable ($10 for a glass, $40 for a bottle). I look forward to returning and to checking out brunch as well!
author: Christine G.

description:
Barzotto is a nice, new pasta-centric spot in the Mission. We came by on a weeknight and were able to snag a table even though it was pretty busy.

Here's how it works: order at the counter, find your own table, and wait for food/drinks to come out. Not sure I really like this fast-casual concept - I feel too much pressure to order quickly and then find seats.

The menu has a variety of pastas, salads, and a couple mains. We ordered the ribbons pappardelle with slow braised beef and mushrooms, and the porchetta board, which was plenty of food for the two of us.

The pappardelle was good, with lots of mushroom-y flavor. The pasta was perfectly cooked with just the right amount of sauce.

The porchetta was disappointing - I love pork, but thought that the meat was a little dry in the center, and not crispy and crackly enough on the outside. Overall a little bland, but the side accoutrements were good.

Overall, nice establishment but I feel like Barzotto misses the mark and there are so many other amazing pasta places in the Mission.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Gotta hand it to the people in BARZOTTO.  Best customer service, warm hospitality, and clean creative Italian pasta dishes makes me think this brand new restaurant looks like home!  I went inside near the entrance a few times just to look at very cute unique pasta shapes.  This time, I came here for lunchtime the very first time.  Not bad seeing the narrow walkway towards the end of the dining area.  Though the seats look and feel comfortable enough, I could see the chefs in the cooking station making pasta.  Of course, I would decide to buy a package of pasta to go for just $5.

Instead of waiter service which it takes a waiter to come to my table, I get to order food and drink and give cash to the cashier.   Excellent!!  Now I have nothing to worry about paying later!  Just like back in Veganburg, except I wait for the food to come.    Let's see, I had San Pellegrino Flavored Water, my gluten free pasta dish, and Cabbage & Kale.  No need for a gelato; I'd head to Arizmendi next door for some dessert.  I thought I wanted the Italian spritzer in a tall glass, but I never thought I had a canned blood orange soda.  For my pasta dish, I had gluten free...strozzapreti?  I thought about having gluten free version of Lumache Snails, ones that are among other shaped colored pastas in the see through glass as I pictured them.  (Sigh) At least what I had is gluten free, which is way better than the egg flavored version.  Those so called "priest stranglers" were chewy even in tomato sauce seasoned with parmesan and topped with ricotta cream.  No matter how small the whole portion in the dish, it looked and taste good in one piece.  Cabbage and Kale looked and taste excellent as well.  With the right amount of ginger vinaigrette and some crispy lentils, these colorful greens are ready to show its edibility.

I'm glad I've chosen BARZOTTO in my must-visits.  They have some varieties of unique colorful shaped pastas.  Why go for same old spaghetti, lasagna, or ravioli when I'm on a hunt for other different kinds?  Anyways, I'm perfectly satisfied with an Italian restaurant.  I might be coming back for the second time if the menu changes.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Great spot!  Love their pastas,canalloni, popordelle,is awesome!!! Super tasty!  The ambiance and lighting is perfect for that eveydate
author: Jerry W.

description:
A hip and vibrant eatery for Italian! I would definitely recommend this place for people looking for fast service, quality food, and good portions. 
I had the pork and it was cooked well, 4/5
The pasta I picked was Cresta Di Gallo and that was fantastic, 5/5 would definitely order it again. They have a selection of other pasta dishes too that looks amazing - will have to come back soon!
author: Lucy G.

description: Tasty lunch spot - had the pasta shells with marinara and heavenly lemon zest and pepper seasoned ricotta. Also fun watching the staff make focaccia!
author: Steve R.

description:
3rd time coming here! Definitely recommend it, the pasta is amazing and for Italian food it's surprisingly light and well balanced. I did find the prices to be a bit steep, but ah well it's San Francisco. 

Only real bad review is their roasted vegetable pasta I had once. Honestly, just wasn't to my liking nor anyone I tried to pass it off to. I just assume it was a fluke, because all the other pasta dishes have left me wanting more.
author: Christy C.

description:
This spot was a lot more casual than I thought it was going to be when I looked at the menu online but I was fine with it. You order at the counter, seat yourself, and even grab your own water from the self-serve station. For such a low key environment, I thought the pasta was still very high quality. 

All of the pastas I tried (the spaghetti, the bucatini, the fazzoletti) were all fresh and perfectly cooked, with lots of rich sauces, cheese, or meats to accompany them. Add an egg on any of them for $2 extra and you won't regret it! I noticed that they also sell fresh and dry pastas and jars of sauce to take out, which I would highly recommend for those who are trying to impress someone by pretending to be a fabulous home cook. The little gem salad was also delightful. 

The one dish that didn't impress me was the board with the half chicken and pickled veggie condiments. I just didn't think the chicken was that flavorful or tender. I don't eat pork but the photos I've seen of the pork board seemed much more impressive, so I'd recommend giving that a shot. 

The space is very simple and clean - pretty much your typical modern, trendy SF spot - but really all you need to know about is the pasta. Give it a shot!
author: Christina P.

description:
Literally Souvla but for pasta and American Italian.

Little gem salad was fresh and dressed perfectly. Crispy leaves and crunchy watermelon radishes. A feast for the eyes and the mouth. 

Papardelle was eggy and smothered in that shredded stewed  beefy goodness. 

Good prices, not crazy busy, and decent drink options.

They even do a frozen dessert with toppings like Souvla, but better imo. 

Can't wait to try the chicken.
author: Megan L.

description: The wait for pasta was way too long. I got the spaghetti dish, was really looking forward to it... was very disappointed. It tasted as if they just put tomato sauce on the pasta. The portions were way too small and the wait for the pasta was too long. Not worth trying.
author: Vivi F.

description:
I simply just love the vibe of this place haha. We stopped by the place before a bar hopping night on a Saturday for dinner. it was just a random pick after we got out from the Bart station. There was a waitlist on the door but fortunately, it didn't take too long. You order at the counter before you get seated, which was kinda easy~. We ordered a Fazzoletti Pasta (with slow braised beef), turkey meatballs, and half of a chicken. EVERYTHING WAS SO GOOD! I loved loved loved the pasta I ordered with handkerchief pasta, braised beef, mushrooms. It was just the pasta of my dreams! The turkey meatball was also that good that I almost ate 3 of them... the seasonings and the sauce, ugh I just couldn't help taking bites! They half chicken was great too with some vegetables on the side. The presentation was beautiful! 

We did had two class of lighter wines to start the night and they were both yummm.
author: Melissa H.

description:
After a couple months from our trip to Italy, we were craving good Italian pasta big time. We went to several expensive and trendy pasta restaurants to try to fill that void, but nothing could fulfill the cravings we were having. Until, we came to Barzotto. 
Barzotto, hit the spot. 

Their fresh pasta was spot on with it's gumminess/chewy texture. The sauces used was light and flavorful for 2 of the dishes we tried. It reminded us of the fresh pasta laboratories they have in Italy. Simple and good, not crazy fancy and expensive like the other pasta places in the city we tried going to to fulfill our void. Would definitely come here again when my cravings are at an all time high.
author: Julie B.

description:
I really wish that I did not have to take two stars off for the service, but I really do. Maybe, it should have been a bit expected since this was an order at the counter, self-serve type restaurant. 

First off, we put our name down on the waitlist clipboard after another party and waited just right outside. After 10 minutes, we kept seeing people walking in and being seated at a table right away by a host so we went in to inquire and he said all the tables were taken and there was only first come, first serve bar seating left... Fine, we'll deal. 

I was really in between two pastas and when we were ready to go up and order, I told him that it was my first time here and what I was in between and if he could make a suggestion or feel free to just surprise me. The first thing that came out of the very same person who wasn't paying any attention to the waitlist clipboard was that he was busy and didn't have time for this... Lol ok, I was so taken aback from his response that I went with the safe route and spaghetti it was. That wasn't just it though, from this particular host. My friend tried to pay with a $100 bill and the same guy said he was too busy to get change, but my friend didn't have his debit card on him. Gee, too busy to handle money at a restaurant?! What an outrageous request... Mind you, the restaurant wasn't bustling with people waiting out the door or anything...

Ok now... aside from that, the food was amazing. My party of 4 all got different pastas and we tasted each of one another's and it is definitely worth going back to... but, I think we'll opt out for delivery or take-out instead which they seem to be huge on. It's well-portioned, sauce to meat ratio is on point, and the flavor is just bursting through the noodles. Pricy? Kind of expected for SF, but even more so annoying with the experience we had there. It's definitely worth trying and the food itself will earn another visit from me the next time that I'm in town.
author: Kathy L.

description: I spent $30 on a glass of wine and what was essentially a bowl of pasta with sauce and cheese. No meat or anything fancy. I had asked for a side of bread, but you can only get bread if you pay for another $4, which is basically the Italian equivalent of having to pay extra for fries at a burger place. The pasta itself was actually pretty tasty but I left still kinda hungry, so for that amount of money I think that's wack. The staff was not unfriendly, but didn't seem to care at all that I was there. I doubt I would come back here but this place is a good alternative if beretta has a long wait and you wanted Italian food and you don't want to walk further than a block.
author: Adam M.

description: Opens at 5:30 pm, was the second to get in here.  Order, pay, and then sit down. The food comes to your table. Tip:  order a few things only and then order from the servers the noodles when you are really ready to eat them or else everything comes at once and the noodles get cold and it's really hard to enjoy food when it is cold.  The roasted pork (porchetta) platter seems to be on every table except ours.  Good thing I didn't see the yelp photos or else I would have ordered that.  What called out was the kale and cabbage salad with fried lentils, very light on dressing, the way I like it.  It was so hardy.  The beets ($7) were wonderful, reminds me of a dessert than a side with a few dallops of fresh ricotta cheese, sprinkle of pistachio (which you really can't taste).  We got two pastas:  the beef pappardelle (Ribbons. Slow braised beef, mushroom, parmesan) was so rich in flavor and the long spaghetti had very fresh clams (a bit of a spicy zing) was okay and el dente. The total bill $72.00 with tax and tips.  You pick the portion size: small or regular with a difference by a few dollars.  Get according to your appetite! We got the small pappardelle and large spaghetti. Small actually was enough, but when you are hungry, you just can't control yourself. I like the ambiance but not the "rock" background music, which didn't quite fit into the atmosphere.  The music rattled and was unnerving rather than give the relaxing zen enjoyment of food feeling.  They have ice cream sundaes which we skipped since we were full.  They sell fresh pastas 1/2 pound for $5.00 which changing assortments each day.
author: Helen L.

description:
Rating based SOLELY off the dish I ordered. I ordered a veggie pasta dish. I had the Cock's Comb... came with cauliflower, garlic, chili, and almonds. Sounded good on paper...better than it actually tasted unfortunately. The flavor was unique for sure, but not somethign I would want to have a lot of. I didn't even bother finishing my plate because I just wasn't that into it.

I tried a bite of my boyfriend's pasta - pappardelle with beef and mushrooms - and I really enjoyed the flavor. Significantly more than mine. But he didn't think it was worth it. He was unimpressed with the actual pasta.

I also tried my friend's little shells with squash and kale. Flavors were okay-good but I wouldn't order it again if I were there.

My other friend's carbonara looked freaking delicious but I didn't try it. Next time I come I'll definitely have to try that instead. 

I was bummed they didnt have their signature bucatoni - it's seasonal. So i will definitely have to come back and try it out. I'll update my review when I come back :)

I also didn't like that they charge for bread...and you only get two small pieces of focaccia. It's good focaccia, don't get me wrong, but I guess after having dated an Italian guy way back when, I've been trained to be salty when bread is not complimentary. Also, I did feel the dishes were a bit on the pricier side. Especially for a place where you order at the counter and seat yourself.
author: Josephine T.

description: Bonnie was my server tonight. Absolutely incredible smile and service. The pasta was on point. Over all just a wonderful experience.
author: Grant M.

description:
Barzotto has become a regular for me--the perfect combination of delicious food, convenience, and friendly service.

The house-made pasta is the best I've had. I highly recommend the pappardelle with braised beef, spaghetti with meatballs, cockscomb with cauliflower, and the porchetta. You order at the counter (including optional wine), and the pasta comes out steaming, al dente, and with a range sauces, anywhere from very hearty and filling (pappardelle) to light and fun (cockscomb).

The hosts, especially the lady with the tattoos, are so cool.

Note that serving sizes are on the small side, so order a "large" if you're very hungry or want leftovers.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Love it love it love it!! 
Great atmosphere, friendly service and really good pizza! We had to wait in line for 10 minutes but it worth it. I really enjoyed dining at the bar facing the pizza oven watching those two guys making pizzas so fast!
author: Fabio T.

description: Great neighborhood find - delicious food and staff is very attentive.  Wine list is limited but good enough.
author: Hlb C.

description:
[Out-of-Towner Review]

Carb seeking, carb eating!

Heading to the City the evening before the Giant Race, we shopped until we were carb depleted. We set to Yelp to see what pasta slangin' place was near us or looked delicious! Unfortunately, SF has plenty of highly rated 'pasta' spots, so we were at a loss. I decided we should try out one that was listed under "Hot and New."

This little spot is right between a corner gas station, at the end of a building on a street. It's small, don't blink, you may miss it. The vibe is really cute and laid back, dark, yet relaxed. The signage outside made me laugh, because it was too fitting for my life! As we walked in, we noticed how small this place was, another surprise. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I don't think this was it. That's not to say that it was a bad thing, just more of a preface to where my mind was.

This is one of those places that runs a little differently than a traditional restaurant. You order at the counter, you get a little geo tracker (might be a slight exaggeration), TRY to find a seat, then your food is delivered. Lucky for us, right before we ordered a couple left and ran to snag our seat, so we could order without hoping to find a seat. Our backup plan was to order to-go if we couldn't get a seat, but we did :)

Even though the place is somewhat small, they have a variety of seating. They have bar style seating that outlooks the front window and also that can look into the kitchen area. They have high tables and regular tables for various sizes of parties. I think they are also set up with a few tables where parties can share the tables. We enjoyed a two top right along the wall with a cute light above us. Their purse hooks are genius, right in the middle, beneath the table. It was perfect, it never hit either of us under the table and was perfectly out of the way, not on the ground. It's the little things.

Like I said, the menu is not that large. I went with the Spaghetti, side of Turkey Meatballs, and the House Made Focaccia. J was adventurous and went with the Italian Ramen. Yup, you read that correctly! They were trying something new and it seemed like a cool concept. They also had dessert on the menu and I really wanted to try it, but I wasn't sure our stomachs could handle all that food. That's the problem with pre-ordering and paying for your meal, you don't get to order as you please. Also, I think it's weird to tip on service before you receive it. Especially since I didn't know exactly how the joint was ran -- do I get my food somewhere, do they serve me and never check on our table?

We each ordered a glass of Cab Sav, which was $10 or we could have went with a bottle for $40. They don't have a large variety of wines, but they have one of each of the basics. We were splurging, so we went for it! After I paid, they poured our glasses for us and I carried them back to the table.

Come to find out they hand out little trackers, that look like traditional restaurant buzzers, but cooler that also can tell the employees where you are sitting. They looked like little space age disks. There was a water station for self-service, they also had small plates and additional utensils there if you needed them.

I really enjoyed the handmade pasta, it was dense and plenty in quantity. I also enjoyed that their spaghetti was a cheese base, not a red sauce base. It was simple and delicious. I will say, the red sauce that comes with the focaccia and the meatballs has some heat. Again, we all know I'm a wimp, so my mouth was on fire, but I kept eating it because it was tasty. I wanted to eat the two squares of focaccia all to myself, but I shared. J's Italian Ramen looked gorgeous, plated very lovely. However, it wasn't his favorite dish -- he did enjoy the fact that they had fired pork skin inside and the house made noodles were good. He just would have preferred a different broth, they used a chicken broth to keep with the Italian vibe. We both enjoyed the meatballs, even though their flavoring left something to be desired. More than anything I felt the heat of the red sauce, rather than any seasoning to the meatballs. Their portion size is very generous, which I can appreciate.

After we were done, the owner, Marco, happened to wander by and ask us about our dinner. Mainly he wanted to know about the Italian Ramen. J told him the truth about how he felt about it. We also learned they are only 3 weeks new and still working on things. He took the corrective criticism like a professional and said that they might try a different broth to bring out more flavor to the dish. He did confirm the red sauce has heat, so I knew I wasn't crazy ;) I can totally appreciate how this owner runs his business. He cares about his customers, his food, and his aesthetics. It wasn't our favorite, but it was a great experience overall!

It's worth a try and it still has room to grow to become better!
author: Steph G.

description: Delicious pastas and focaccia. Loved the mushroom pasta and they recommended a wonderful wine by the glass. Order at the counter and have a seat kind of place, but food is top notch!
author: Anna S.

description:
The owners of Barzotto must be chuckling right now, since they've gotten us fooled real good. The word "barzotto" is actually Italian slang for something highly inappropriate, but pretty darn funny. Well, what are you waiting for? Go look it up on Urban Dictionary! PG-13 though.

I came here at 7:00pm for a Tuesday dinner date and we were able to find seats right away. Both of us ordered the fazzoletti partly because of the cashier's recommendation, but mostly because braised beef always sounds like a terrific idea. This dish had its fair share of shortcomings though. I couldn't really taste the rosemary, the pasta itself should have been more al dente, and the sauce was too oily. To end on a more positive note, Barzotto's prices are very reasonable and their portions are sized just right.
author: Miko B.

description:
When you first walk into Barzotto, you'll immediately see the fresh made pasta in the display, ready to be taken home for a delicious meal. You order first, and then you find a seat, but if you're in on a busy night, I'd advise that you send your friend ahead to get a table. It gets crowded, fast.

I came in for dinner on Barzotto's third night in business and ordered breadsticks, turkey meatballs, bucatini, and porchetta for my boyfriend and I to share. I'd pass on the breadsticks next time, but everything else was AMAZING.

The turkey meatballs - huge, and covered in a super delicious marinara.

The bucatini - pancetta, tomato, chili, and breadcrumbs. The pasta was almost elastic. Super chewy in the most satisfying way. I had to resist licking my plate clean.

The porchetta - a large board of meat with flavorful, juicy pork and an addicting crunch of skin.

Barzotto is sure to be my neighborhood go to. The pasta is unbelievable, and if you're in the mood for something rich, the porchetta is fantastic. Barzotto, I'm glad you exist. Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Christina S.

description:
Didn't know what to expect when I walked in but oh my gosh is this the best pasta I've ever tasted. I ordered the pappardelle and the noodles were cooked to perfection and the beef was tender. I also ordered the side of beets and focaccia bread which were delicious as well. I honestly don't know what my favorite part was. My only complaint is that my pasta came out 10 minutes after I ordered (awesome) but the rest of my food came out 25 minutes later, well after I had finished my entree. The host was very apologetic and had to check up on my order twice before the rest of it showed up. I understand they were busy but I have no idea why it took so long. 

Portion sizes are pretty large and I was a little shocked to be spending $55 on a solo dinner (including a glass of wine) but overall my experience was a pleasant one.
author: Morgan R.

description:
I love fresh pasta and was so excited to hear about a new pasta restaurant opening. Barzotto is the kind of place where you order and pay at the counter and they bring the food out to you. I really love the concept of fine dining level food served in a casual setting. 

We came on a Sunday where they also had a few brunch items and so ordered some from the regular menu and some from the brunch menu.

Fazzoletti with slow braised beef and mushrooms ($17) was awesome. The sauce was flavorful and the fresh pasta was just cooked to perfection.

The Spaghetti with pecorino, parmesan and black pepper ($10) however was not as good. Flavor was there but I wish it was less thick and more saucy. When it cooled down a bit, it clumped together and was not pleasant to eat.

Maple glazed porchetta ($14) was super tender and flavorful. This was a brunch item. The porchetta was really tender and flavorful. I suspect it's the same porchetta on their regular menu but just topped with maple glaze. I usually don't like meats sweet but this was great. 

Turkey meatballs ($8) was not the best dish. It might be the seasoning that was not my cup of tea.

Focaccia ($5) was great. It came soft, fluffy and warm.

Stuffed french toast was too bready for me. I understand french toast is bread but this one was dense.

Service was very good for being casual.

Street parking is a challenge in the area.

Would be back soon! Hope the pasta changes on the menu but that they keep the porchetta.
author: Andy W.

description: This place is fantastic!  The pasta was excellent and the meatballs were delish! The pappardelle dish was ridiculous. The staff was friendly and helpful, I loved the overall vibe and will definitely return soon!
author: Cristina V.

description:
My partner found out about this place from a friend who attended the soft opening. She took me for my birthday and I couldn't be happier.

We ordered the spaghetti and cockscomb as mains, with the little gems salad and bread sticks. At the recommendation of one of the very knowledgeable person taking our order we also got the Vallin syrah to accompany it.

It's mind blowing how much of a difference hand made pasta can make in a dish, and I'm afraid I'll never be able to make pasta at home again after eating at barzotto. Each sauce had distinct flavors that complemented the unique textures of the pasta. The little gems had a great balance of tangy vinegar, fresh herbs, and refreshing yogurt. The bread sticks were a delicious necessity to make sure we got every last drop of tasty sauce.

We finished the night with the spumoni gelato, which I will be returning soon to have again. Since I've exhausted my vocabulary for raving about food all I can do is say that you must order this if you come here.

We ended on a nightcap of the saison, which was apparently made specifically for Barzotto. I never think to order a saison, but I'm glad I tried this one as it was citrusy and refreshing, it was the perfect follow up. I'd also recommend it for pairing with a meal because it was not too heavy.

I'll be adding Barzotto to my list of staples.
author: Patrick S.

description: Came here with friends who I hadn't seen in a long time and caught up over some delicious pasta. Amazing service -- we had Bonnie who was friendly, funny and made our experience special despite this being an order-at-the-counter place. We'll be back!
author: Em S.

description:
The loss of 2 stars is exclusively because of the pricing model here. Easily the most expensive salad I've had in the neighborhood, and a small pasta dish that's usually inhaled in less than 10 minutes will run you up to $16. That being said, the food is phenomenal. The radiatore is cooked and sauced to perfection, the meatballs with the spaghetti are generous and well-seasoned. It's a perfect amount of food for a lunch, and won't weigh you down for the whole afternoon. The service is friendly and I love the half-wall format for the prep kitchen, where you can watch them string the pasta by hand. 

For a counter-service place, where you self-serve your own water and table settings live at the tables, the prices are just a little over the top to justify. At least you don't bus your own table, and the food is delicious enough to keep me coming back.
author: Tessa M.

description: Had a couple pastas and one was pretty funky tasting (something was off)... When we told the server he brought us a different plate of pasta, which was much better. Still, very trendy pastas for a lot of money. Better pastas elsewhere.
author: Hannah S.

description:
Set up reminds me of Vapiano in Germany. Order at counter, get a number and a table, then wait for your food. Only difference is that food here is brought to your table, whereas at Vapiano, you go grab your food from the counter. Good concept, and service here was friendly. 

However, the pastas were sadly lacking. I love pasta. I was originally going to order a salad (trying to be good with my diet and all that), but when I realized BARZOTTO serves fresh pasta, I immediately opted for that instead. 

I ordered the Cresta di Gallo, tossed with cauliflower, chili, garlic, lemon, and topped with almonds. The pasta itself was overcooked, and the cream-based sauce definitely didn't impress--it was a tad too watery and the citrus was overpowering, drowning out the garlic and much of the chili. I didn't finish my dish. 

My friend ordered Spaghetti to share, tossed with pecorino, parmesan, and black pepper, very similar to cacio e pepe. This was disappointing as well. First bite was good because it was cheesy, but the pasta was once again overcooked, and I had to add more pepper to it for a kick. 

Not worth it. As another reviewer said, I'd rather pay more and get excellent pasta than pay less for mediocre pasta. Ambiance was a little loud--bare walls, bare ceilings, bare floors. I had to strain and lean in close to hear people across the table. On the plus side, the service was good and the food came out pretty  quickly. Likely won't come here again though if I were craving pasta.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
When you work around the Mission, you literally have so many food options! Decided to have dinner with a co-worker because we heard this place was new so we checked it out.

We were welcomed by the front staff and were given Dinner menu's. My friend ordered the Strozzapreti and I ordered the Fazzoletti. At first bites, we knew this place was going to be our new "splurge spot". Both tasted AMAZINGLY GOOD. Tender braised beef and smoky mozzarella from our pastas and we are just in awe how tasty our meals were! Perfect portions (my friend had a bit of a hard time at the end since her meal was on the creamy/heavy side). 

Overall, this place is a must if you're ever in the Mission!
author: Kristine C.

description:
Yess!! So glad they finally opened. Going to come here whenever I'm craving mac n cheese but feeling a little classier. 

Highlights: the fresh pasta, obviously; adult spumoni; 40% of the playlist being Regina spektor; snazzy tech at the table; tbh the best eggs I've ever had (on top of anything I want them on).
author: Anna K.

description: Excellent pasta, worth the price when you factor in taste and ability to fill the tum. I love a place where you can order at the counter while the overall experience still feels like fine dining- takes the anxiety out of enjoying a meal out (for someone who dwells on the impending bill process). Ambiance is beautiful and inviting. Branding is on point, service has always been very friendly. Wish I came here more often!
author: E E.

description: Amazing! Gluten-free pasta option, which is so rare for pasta places. And it tasted amazing - my husband couldn't tell it was gluten free. Sauces were delicious, Restaurant is gorgeous. My new favorite local place.
author: Jordan J.

description:
Located on the Valencia strip. Very narrow storefront entrance.  

The order counter is near the front entrance.  There are thick paper menus.  Order, pay, and grab a table.  Your food order is brought to your table.

If you're going to order anything, it's got to be the porchetta platter which the four of us shared.  It's a fairly thick slice of pork with the roasted skin. it comes on a wood platter with some roasted veggies.  We also shared the gem salad and two pasta dishes. Lots of meat on both pasta dishes whereas we agreed we preferred more pasta than meat.

Can you devour the porchetta platter yourself?  Maybe.  Depends how much protein you want to digest.

Overall 3.5 stars.
author: Shirley N.

description: After watching Buzzfeed's worth it series, we decided to take a trip to San Francisco and try this place. We got the extra long noodles and it did not disappoint. It was really food. 5/5 :)
author: Anthony S.

description: Being frugal is my new thing, so dining out has become a luxury and special treat. Barzotto may be super casual, but it's affordable and most importantly, DELICIOUS. A small salad and two pastas were only $50 including tip. Granted, I didn't order any alcohol but I was okay with that because I was already kind of drunk. I scarfed down the papardelle and radiatore like a stupid Hungry Hungry Hippo...totally forgot I was supposed to be on a diet. Oopsie!
author: Suany W.

description: Girls night with friends.  We ordered two salads to share and our own pasta dishes (one of my friends is gluten free). The Chicory Salad was my favorite. The Little Gem salad was quite good too. My pasta dish wasn't that great though. I had the braised beef pappardelle and it was bland. Salt and pepper didn't help it. My friends had the chorizo pasta. One with the regular pasta finished and she loved it, the gluten free choice did not. The best part of the whole night (and the reason it's such a high rating) is the gelato. We shared the coffee one and the caramel/chocolate. Delicious. The gelato saved the night. Would come again for salads and gelato.
author: Diana G.

description:
great handmade pasta and salads--very reasonably priced.

pleasant, professional service. 

order at the counter and they bring your food to you. 

love their soft-serve.
author: Rob S.

description:
This is a nice fast-casual place to eat at if you're looking for good pasta, quick service, and an nice ambiance. It's good for a third or fourth date since it's pretty quick and relatively inexpensive. Or come with a friend or significant other for a casual meal - you'll be in and out in an hour and it's pretty easy to get a table, so its nice.

They have 5 different types of pastas, some salads, and ice cream for dessert. It's a pretty simple menu, but you should be able to find something to suit everyone's tastes. You order at the counter, get a number for your table, and they will bring the food out to you. The food comes pretty quickly, usually within 10-15 min. You can also get fresh or dried pasta to go if you'd like.

I got the bucatini pasta, which had a tomato sauce and pancetta. The noodles were nice and al dente, but the sauces were not overly complicated. Very similar to traditional Italian dishes, the ingredients were minimal so that all the flavors could come out. I wouldn't necessarily say it was the best pasta I've ever had, but it was a solid pasta. Portion size was fine, but slightly on the smaller side than the larger side.

I didn't really care for the focaccia too much ($4 for 2 pieces, with a side of marinara sauce), but that's me. Good place for a fast-casual meal, and I'd come again if I were in the area, but wouldn't make come out of my way to come here, or wait more than 20 min to eat here.
author: Christina L.

description:
2.5 stars. 

I came in the afternoon and ordered a side of meatballs as a snack. First it came out barely warm. After getting a hot serving out instead, the meatballs were just not that tasty. The tomato sauce is mediocre and the meat is just ok. Not a huge fan of this. 

The good thing on the menu is that all wines by the glass are $10 and curated by the sommelier who started Saint Vincent.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Terrible food! Can't believe this place is so well rated. Worst pasta in all of SF! Also veg plate was bad.
author: V V.

description:
Been walking past this place for years now and always kept walking after looking at the menu, thinking it was too expensive. I finally went in tonight since I just cant eat another burrito, and thats all that was close by. Going here was a good decision! I ordered pasta to go and was expecting it to be good but not quite at the level it was. This place rivals some places I have been to in Italy. Great atmosphere and friendly staff. I will be back. 

If only they server a torteloni! Hint.
author: H K.

description:
Very good neighbourhood fast casual restaurant. For the price point of living in the mission-- this is a fairly affordable meal. Sort of like an upscale Noodles & Company. So you order upfront when you walk in, and they give you a buzzer so they can track where you sit and bring your food to you. There's also alcohol here so it really is a great place to just sit with friends and eat and drink!

During presidential debates, they have a special takeout package too! Also come on Sundays or Mondays after 5:30-- daily special is Italian ramen with their famous porchetta-- delicious! 

We had their focaccia which I thought was a bit expensive for two pieces- but super delicious and full of flavour. Wish they offered a bigger chunk. 
My BF and I have only had the pastas and specials here so we can't speak to the meat dishes-- however, I really enjoyed the large chunk of porchetta in the Italian ramen! It was super good, though I found that the ramen could use more broth and more noodles for the price point. Portion sizing here though is enough to satiate. Between the two of us have already ha D most of the pasta menu-- everything has been delicious. The gelato sundaes are amazing too-- get the strawberries one! Sooo good.
author: Christa Lei S.

description: We ordered the papparadelle pasta (amazing - easily our favorite), the meatballs and the porchetta board.  The salsa verde that comes with the porchetta was delicious!  I highly recommend all of these plates, but you need to try the pasta.  I didn't love that you had to pay at the counter.  It sort of ruined the vibe of the night having to keep going up to the counter to order.  I may not come running back here, but I'm glad I tried it and will recommend to others.
author: Elise C.

description: Run, do not walk to this wonderful Italian restaurant!!  Their porchetta is the best I've tasted since I went to Rome.  Their pasta is freshly made and the women who work there could not be nicer.  Don't let the casual atmosphere fool you!  They are very serious about their food!!  Barzotto will always be a first stop of ours when I go to the City!!
author: Nancy R.

description:
Thank God for Yelp! It was my boyfriend's birthday, and he loves panchetta so Yelp led us here tonight. Without ya'll, we totally would've missed this place. Lol I had to keep looking up directions even though it's just up the street from my house to find it.

Loooveed the ambiance of this place--rap in the background and freshly made pasta? Yes, yes, yes! Not even sure why'd you go to Flour + Water when Barzotto is around. 

I felt that seating was plentiful and cozy. And the food was absolutely amazing. We got the panchetta, extra pickles, baked polenta, and pappardelle. Birthday boy loved the crispy on the outside and moist on the inside panchetta. Came with two delightful sauces, one tangy and one sweet to hit all of your flavor buds. Extra pickles were a medley of vegetables with the right amount of zest. Polenta melted in our mouths combined with pesto, red sauce, and burrata. 

Hands down, best pappardelle I have ever tried. I normally refuse to pay for pasta bc I'm just like lol why pay when you can do it yourself at home, but this is soooo worth the $$$$. Like the polenta, it melted in your mouth and was so delicious. My boyfriend thought it was boiled with parmesan and other tasty things because of how much flavor it packed. 

We were full after eating half of what we ordered, but it was so frikkin' good, we ate it all.

Also loved that we got to order up front, and the food came out in great time. Excellent service.
author: Michelle N.

description: I mean... they make their own pasta in-house. Price is reasonable and the food was amazing. The wait can be a bit long, especially if the pasta machine gets "backed" up like it did for us but when the food came out I didn't remember the wait time at all. DELCIOUS!
author: Hannan Z.

description:
Super casual spot to grab some wine and pasta and catch up with friends. Menu is rather limited - a few pastas, couple salads, and a few main (meat) courses, but all is incredibly delicious. I will make particular note of the strozzapreti (SO good), and then, whatever you do, DO the gelato. You will not regret it. 

All wines are $10/glass or $40/bottle, which makes for a reasonably priced outing for groups looking to shoot the breeze over a few bottles of wine. It's a pretty tiny place, though, so groups of more than 3 or 4 may have difficulty finding space. 

Haven't been for brunch yet, but that's on the short list!
author: Amelia B.

description: Best pasta in town! Make sure you order family style and try out all their pasta dishes. It's too good to left out any of them :)
author: Angel C.

description:
I went on a Monday evening for a light dinner with a friend. You order your food at the counter & find a spot to sit & they bring the food to you.

Casual, modern, spacious, and clean. They let us try a bunch of wines before we committed to a medium bodied red. The girl at the counter was friendly & efficient. The place was relatively busy, but there is space between the tables/bar stools and the noise level was fine - no yelling to your dinner date required. 

We ordered only pasta. I had the Fazzoleti. My friend had the Bucatini. I don't eat tomatoes, so ordering at a pasta shop usually means eating a lot of cream sauce for me, but not here. The fazzoleti came with a delicious braised beef and mushroom "sauce." The pasta was perfectly al dente and you could taste that it was made fresh.The portion was not huge but not standard SF tiny, and I'd recommend ordering a salad or a meat if you're really hungry. I thought the price to quality ratio was spot on. 

Can't wait to be back for brunch!
author: Nelya T.

description: Great for delivery. I've never been to the location. Order the pastas, side salad,  and the side of bread. The red pasta sauce is good.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Ok so first time here and on a Monday night the special was "Italian" ramen.  It was far and away the best ramen I have had in the city and better than many places in Japan. 

The tonkatsu broth was deep and rich, and delicious, the ramen noodles were handmade, the pork was perfectly done with crispy edges. Loaded with maitaki and greens and topped with a perfectly soft boiled egg. It was super. Ramen on Sunday and Monday nights only. You won't be disappointed.
author: Karen L.

description: Love the casual yet clean atmosphere but most importantly, the FOOD IS DELICIOUS! Every dish we ordered was AMAZING! The salad, the pastas and the beets were all simple yet fresh and yummy. I will be back again on the future for lunch.
author: Couture A.

description: Disappointed. This was recommended by a friend and was encouraged by the good reviews. However, the pasta was hugely disappointing. We had the pappardelle and the spaghetti / meatballs. The pappardelle was so smothered in butter, you couldn't taste the other ingredients. The spaghetti was only marginally better, a light tomato sauce that could have come from the jar. To top it off, the glasses all had lipstick marks and the table was only partially clean. Better off at beretta up the street.
author: Orange M.

description:
I liked that it wasn't pretentious. You order in the front and they serve you your food when done. 

I got the Grills pasta -- can't go wrong with Burrata! BUT the pasta was a little chewy for my liking. I would recommend the Porchetta... crispy skin reminded me of Chinese BBQ : ) 

Get the salted caramel & dark chocolate sundae!!
author: Silvia Z.

description: SO overrated. Was looking forward to this place bc heard great things. Way over priced for spaghetti you can make at home. Half chicken WA really dry didn't even finish the plate. Portions smaller than anticipated. Fun to try out bc cute location but not worth it.
author: Andrea E.

description:
I came to here on last Sunday morning.
I was expected restaurant, because it is new.
The decor is simple and me and my friend like it.
I must recommend Fazzoletti. It taste like sour and buttery. So yam.!! Mushroom was match so well with beef.
But i don't like bucatini was so dry. Porchetta was so dry and little bit chewy... So sad..
author: Sunkyung J.

description:
Swanky San Francisco pasta joint serving up fresh home made pasta.

Prices are an affordable $12-$17 for an entree with sides and $10 glasses of wine. 
You order at the counter and they bring the food to you as its ready and its surprisingly quick!

The pasta was delicious albeit a medium sized portion, but its ok if you end up splitting the porchetta or getting a side! The pasta was a little too soft/mushy (overcooked or maybe the flour they use)? But the flavors were great; traditional carbonara with a poached egg and a savory raddiatore with broccoli rabe and nduja. The porchetta is definitely worth it! Tenderloin wrapped in pork belly; crispy skin, rendered fat, a tender and moist loin all in one package served with a sweet jam and a spicy gremolata as well as some pickled vegetables.  

Very modern decor lined with marble slabs and pop music, but I'd definitely come back if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Chad S.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for awhile after following the Instagram feed and seeing all the daily specials everything always looks amazing. Ended up here for Mother's Day lunch and had a great experience. It was a mellow afternoon and although not all of us were there we were welcomed to sit down and have complimentary coffee and wait for the last in our party to arrive. 
The food was great! We order a 1/2 chicken and 3 pasta dishes! Way too much for the 4 of us but the leftover pasta was amazing for dinner the next night. I will definitely be back for dinner to hopefully try one of the specials I'm always swooning over on Instagram!
author: Michaela M.

description: Super cute place in the Mission. We stopped here before our night out and thought the food was delicious! My friend and I shared the porchetta and ribbons pasta and let me say that the porchetta is extremely delicious! Perfect ratio of pork fat to lean meat. I will say that the pasta portions are not very generous which can be a little frustrating since it's not cheap. Fun nonetheless!
author: Helen F.

description:
Yelp Review

1. Staff Friendliness: 5
2. Staff Knowledge: 5
3. Staff Efficiency: 5
4. Transaction Time: 5
5. Order Wait Time: 5
6. Register Counter Cleanliness: 5
7. Kitchen / Prep Area Cleanliness: 5
8. Dining Area Cleanliness: 5
9. Restroom Cleanliness: N/A
10. Storefront Cleanliness: 5
11. Food Handling (i.e. clean hands): 5
12. Food/Drink Presentation (i.e. wrapping, boxing, pouring): 5
13. Food/Drink Preparation (i.e. made with care): 5
14. Food/Drink Value: (i.e. worth the price): 5
15. Food/Drink Taste: 5

(Total score) / (Questions Answered)  = (Yelp!)
author: Charlie A.

description:
Conclusion: Go to North Beach for decent Italian. Ugh.

Upside: Cute decor. Props to whoever designed the interior.

Downsidesssss: Bad service - waitresses look unapproachable and cranky and walk by without a peep.

I find it to have a weird business model for Italian dinner. Like really? What is this a Starbucks? I was encouraged to sit down then come back to the counter to order and pay for my meal and tip before I  get to taste it?

I went with a friend and she said  the place feels like a restaurant you'd find in a hostel... Poor service from college kids,  quick and bland overpriced food.
