Decided on the cockscomb and there was no Italian flavor, unless a shitload of garlic counts? This place seems to have a new age hippy flavorless take on Italian. I ended up pouring the poor excuse of marinara  (that came with my focaccia bread) all over my pasta. That didn't help... I didn't even eat it after that. Sooooooo bad. I don't even get offered freshly grated cheese on my pasta?
author: Jessica D.

description: Cozy, hip and delicious! I'd say it's in the 20-30 range if you don't get any drinks. A glass of wine is 10$. But w two more people, we each got a pasta and shared their pork dish and some focaccia bread. I'd happily return for more of the pesto spaghetti I got!!
author: Sofia C.

description:
In nutshell, Barzotto is good, but not great. 

We ordered:  

1. A little gem salad (small). 1.5/5. I'm a salad lover but this was just a-okay. It was boring and not well-balanced. I normally devour salads if they're good. Wouldn't get this again. Too blah.

2. The focaccia. 2/5. Tasty enough I suppose, but we have other places we frequent that provide much better bread for free (complementary with meal, that is). In terms of cost/value, this was really a 1 or 0 out of five. $4 for two small pieces of focaccia and way more sauce than could properly be sopped up by said amount of bread? Meh. They must be wasting a lot of the tomato sauce unless they provide additional focaccia for free (no idea if they do).

3. The pasta with beef. We ordered the larger portion and although it didn't look that big, I was stuffed to the point of being in a food coma after three bites. Very tasty. 4.5/5.

4. The half chicken. Aesthetically exquisite per Yelp pics and why I wanted to try Barzotto in the first place, but the flavors ultimately didn't appeal to me. It was very tender and cooked well but I wasn't a fan in terms of how it actually tasted. 2/5 for the flavor; 4/5 for presentation and tenderness. 3/5 overall. Wouldn't order again unless they change the recipe to taste better. 

Finally, even though I wasn't a big fan of the food, I planned ahead and ordered efficiently, unlike the couple ahead of us, who apparently were completely unfamiliar with the menu and asked umpteen questions despite the line behind them. 

Please don't be those people. I'm a patient person but my patience was put to the test and them some :P. We took less than a minute to order what the couple in front of us spent 5-10 minutes ordering. Blargh. 

FWIW, I get the concept behind places like Barzotto, Souvla, Media Noche, etc., (e.g. fast casual/fancy), but I can't say that I genuinely enjoy the experience of going to said places. Not yet, anyway.
author: Maya B.

description:
I've been to Barzotto a few times now, and it is gooood. 

There is a lack of good pasta places in this city. Places that other people think are good, I think is pretty subpar. So I'm pretty picky. 

The problem with BARZOTTO is that it's too good. The pasta is so good, I feel a bit weird when I just spent $17 for a bowl of what I would call... pretty exquisite pasta and I'm in and out of there in 15 mins. 

This is because of their take-out style ordering system. You order at the counter and you take your tag and sit down. The food comes out usually in 5 mins. 

I have no problem with fast food... but I feel like the food is so good, it is deserving of a slower pace.  Maybe enjoy it with an app. Some waiter service. Slow it down and enjoy the meal. 

Someone said that the chef is from Flour + Water, which is great. Because I've never been able to go to Flour + Water because I could never get a reservation. So it's very nice I get to try their creations... But then, I want the full experience. Which perhaps I could get at Flour + Water. But I could never get a reservation. Do you see the cycle here?

Anyhow... I will still go to this place from time to time. But I wish I could enjoy it a bit more fully.
author: Bonnie H.

description: We really enjoyed the fresh pasta here. We also ordered the porchetta which was delicious and a starter salad which was a little too acidic for me but helped balance all the carbs and heavy porchetta. We'd go back here, it's a cool atmosphere and casual ordering.
author: Carey T.

description: Pretty amazing pasta in a new format. It's almost like quick service but the quality of food is top notch. You order at the front, grab a table number, and wait for 10 mins max for your dish. And despite the irregular format, the food is just as good as fine dining Italian. Definitely recommend it.
author: Matt L.

description: The snail pasta with the ricotta is amazing. It has a bit of lemon zest. The flatbread with sauce is also good.
author: Martha S.

description: The pasta was barely edible. We ordered the carbonara   and parppardelle. The carbonara was like a soup. We were able to eat the parppardelle, just meh. But the carbonara was terrible (have you had carbonara soup before? Want to try?) Worse than that was that they didn't even ask us why we didn't eat the food. As if the the workers didn't even care about the restaurant.
author: Rene G.

description:
Great wine selection, by the glass, and reasonably priced.

Food way too salty. Won't be back as a result.
author: Zach M.

description: While offering fast Italian food, quality is sacrificed. The salad was one of the worst salads I have eaten in SF, the dressing was minimal which was for the best as it was overwhelming sweet and inedible. The pasta was fine- but very bland and not memorable. I will not be back. The red wine was however delicious- perhaps stick to the wine here.
author: Amy S.

description: I am a pasta enthusiast! So when I found this place by my house that served house-made pasta in a casual setting, I was very excited! Nonetheless, this place is disappointing. I sat at a table , and the small plates had a layer of dust. The water jugs and silverware also seemed to have a white film on them ( maybe dishwasher residue?) The pasta was good, but tasted just like the kind I make at home, and was overpriced. Additionally, when I asked for water, the waiter said "I'll get it, but usually you'd get it from over there". Wait, what? Why do we tip (at the beginning when you order, by the way) if you have to get your own water? What service are we tipping for? Overall, this place was very average...a place to stop if you are in a rush. I would give it another chance.
author: Syd P.

description: Not enough places in SF give you fancy pasta on demand like barzotto. No reservation needed just waltz in get good food and leave with a carb belly. I always get the cockscomb pasta and what ever is the special pasta . Their bread is homemade and Delish
author: Laura G.

description: We had bucatini(very good!) and cockscomb (flavorless!). The roast chicken (pretty good, but similar to a rotisserie chicken I could buy at Boston market). The side of beets was flavorless. I liked the no frills approach to sitting and ordering food. And there was no wait on a sat night despite the restaurant being pretty full of people. Overall, it was an ok food experience. Staff were all nice, except that no one greeted us when we entered the door looking pretty lost as to how things worked. I wouldn't return for another visit.
author: Cathy D.

description: Stopped by Barzotto for brunch on Sunday. Ordered pork meatballs - I really liked them. My friend got eggs Benedict which looked good. I wasn't a big fan of the potatoes on the plate. They seemed burnt. My husband got ribbons pasta which was very delicious. The only downside of the whole experience was I requested if I could add a soft egg to my order of meatballs, and they were not willing to do that. Not sure why was it an issue, when they can add it to the pasta. Oh well, I will still go back. The food is good.
author: Chet L.

description: We tried three pastas and a bottle of wine. All were decent enough, but for the price I would have liked a more pleasant dining experience. We were at the long table near the door, and I was cold even with my coat on. One of the booths probably would have been cozier.
author: Meredith S.

description:
Came here last night and enjoyed it. Pasta was great, salad was interesting and delicious. They were out of the porchetta so ill have to come back for that. Just a couple of important things not listed on their website:
You order at the front desk, you do NOT have a server. I'm ok with this idea but I didn't like that our food came out all at once. There's no way to stagger apps, entrees, dessert. You order everything at once and they bring it out and then no one checked on us. I'm not really sure what you're tipping for but that's not a big deal to me.
author: Sfgal S.

description: I liked it. Went in with a friend, the food was good.The place seem clean. Service is fast
author: Érica T.

description: I'm always on the hunt for the best pasta and I'd say this is up there on my top 5 SF pasta list. You know they're good when they can even make the spaghetti special.
author: Aakash P.

description:
Great service and hipstery atmosphere with bland and boring food.

Focaccia was delicious.  But the pasta was bland and blah.  The added chicken was gross.  I didn't think it was gonna be uncut dark meat pieces when I added chicken.

Totally cramped tables and dinning area.

Very overpriced as well.

I'd pass if you are looking for Italian food.
author: Chewy C.

description: Decent good freshly made pasta :) I ordered the almond pasta (sorry, forgot the name) it was good, not too heavy not too light. Although I do hope the portion can be bigger but It's San Francisco...sigh, I get it.
author: Wing C.

description: This place is befuddlingly delicious. You'll be like, "How did they get that porchetta so crispy on the outside and so juicy on the inside? Wow, it's called little gem salad...but it's so big!? That braised beef fazzoletti! Barzotto is billed as "fine casual",  but is it casual enough for me to lick the slow braised beef sauce clean off the plate? Can I really fit an Italian Gelato with nitro-infused Stumptown coffee? I didn't even know that was a thing. Oh yeah, and this only cost us how much???" Wow. Wow. Wow. So many questions,  so many sumptuous answers.
author: Eduardo C.

description:
I'm not a review person but I really had to talk about my experience here.
I'll keep it very brief.
The food is very good, no complaints at all. The only reason I won't be back is the prices. I brought a few friends, got a bottle of wine, ordered food, it came out very very fast. The only thing is that we had ordered the ravioli, which was $12 a plate, and it had only come with 12 pieces of ravioli spread thin on a plate. The ravioli, although delicious, was not filling whatsoever. Come on, $1 a ravioli seems crazy to me.
To their credit, when pointed out, they did try to correct it by offering complimentary dishes. We didn't take them up on it, but the friendly staff and delicious food is the reason I'm still giving a four star rating despite having little desire to return.
author: Jessica G.

description: This place was amazing! The food, service and atmosphere were all top notch! It was perfect for us. We were looking for some excellent food but didn't have a lot if time. No worries at Barzotto. The dishes arrived in under 10 minutes! The little gem salad is so refreshing and the porchetta platter is not only a work of art but also a culinary masterpiece. The pork was super tender with just the right amount of crackly pork skin! Yummmm!The giardinera is a perfect compliment to the dish as well. We will definitely be back many times over. They've really mastered the fast, fine and casual concept!
author: Naji D.

description: Good food and excellent service. There was a misunderstanding on my order and I received Radiatore after ordering Reginelle. They immediately owned up and  offered both dishes at no extra cost. The focaccia was served with tomatoes sauce that comes pretty close to the one my Italian grandmother used to make.
author: Elena M.

description: This review is for a take order. The food was packaged in a cardboard box that got stuck to pasta so I had to throw it out. The pasta did not seem fresh or evenly cooked. Some parts were hard and stale while others mushy.
author: Charlotte N.

description:
Meh. We had the porchetta board, Italian salad, and the cresta di gallo. You probably don't know me, but if you did, you'd know that I don't leave pieces of pork on the table. We left over half of our porchetta board on the table, and even dissuaded people in line from ordering it. It wasn't good, at least not tonight. The meaty bits were dry, and the fatty bits were gristly. I actually added salt from the salt shaker... something slow cooked pork should NEVER need. 

Our pasta was... pasty! There was a clear imbalance of flavors, or the pasta was cooked too long, it was hard to tell which. Also, all of the wait staff pronounced it guy-oh, which is the spanish pronunciation, but not the Italian. The Italian salad honestly tasted like something you could find at your run of the mill salad bar, even at, *gasp* Domino's. There was really nothing original about it.  I know it was the 3rd day, but things were not going well. The woman pouring wine seemed to know what she was doing, but the gentleman taking orders and ringing people up was just... he didn't know much about food or wine. He couldn't even pronounce montepulciano, which may seem snobbish of me to mention, except that there are only 3 reds by the glass on the menu. 

Alas, I hope this place survives, since I've been hankering for a good neighborhood joint since Heart Wine Bar left the space years ago. But Fiore Caffe up the street satisfies our need for pasta and European wines so well that I can't imagine returning here unless many things change.
author: Licinia I.

description:
This place is so great. Order at the counter, take a seat, get a plate of awesome handmade pasta. It's sort of like a cross between a cafe and an Italian bistro. I love that you can order at the counter but they bring your food. It's casual but nicely done. 

The pass is great. I went back for seconds and basically had two lunches at once because it was so good.
author: Miles G.

description: Great first dinner in San Francisco. Great neighborhood vide and the food is amazing. Super fun to sit at the bar and watch the cooks. The high ceilings make the place feel big and airy. The roasted chicken was perfect. Actually everything was perfect. This would be a regular spot for us if we lived here for sure.
author: Candi D.

description: We had catered lunch at work today from Barzotto.  I'm doing low-carb during the week, so I didn't try any of the pastas, but the pork meatballs were the best meatballs I've ever had in my life, including from my Southern Italian gramma.  The sauce was outstanding, as well.  WOW.  I'll be visiting for pasta on cheat day.  :-)
author: Raymond P.

description: Met the chef across the street. She was too humble to really plug her own place, so her friends did it for her when they heard my friend and I were looking for (wait for it...) pasta. She told us to tell them she sent us. What we got was a MIND-BLOWING papardelli (sp?) dish with the most tender and flavorful slow-braised beef, a delicious snail red sauce and ricotta dish, a bottle of wine and some tasty gelato for dessert - on the house. Thanks to Michelle and her great staff for giving me an experience that forced me to drag myself back on Yelp.
author: Alana K.

description:
What's good fam it's ya boy Teddi Portuano here about to give Barzoto that Teddi P treatment.

Y'all probably here lookin for some dank pasta post blizzy and let me tell ya, you in luck boy. Barzoto got some of the best pasta I've had. For real though, idk what they doin back in that kitchen but the joints are FIRE!

Here's what's a bit whack tho... these folks make you get yo bum off your seat for errythang. You gotta pay up front takeout style for all ya grub. That's cool n all when you order that main pasta dish, but what if ya girl decides she wants some bread sticks mid meal? You gotta get yo butt up walk to the front and order her those breadsticks. And that ain't cool.

Tune in for more from SF's favorite playa Teddi P.
author: Teddi P.

description: I shared porchetta and cockscomb pasta with one friend for dinner. Not too heavy meal and simple. Great interior and lights.
author: Jieun J.

description: Delicious homemade pastas, bread, sauces and pickled items. We eat here a lot but some do take outs. It's a hidden gem.
author: Rob I.

description: I was looking for a casual Italian restaurant for my boyfriend's birthday, and decided on Barzotto based on the glowing reviews. We were not disappointed! I emailed the restaurant to find out when the best time would be to come so we didn't have to wait too long (since they don't take reservations), and the owner, Mark, responded very quickly. He and his staff went way out of their way to ensure my pasta loving boyfriend had a great meal. They even reserved us seats at the counter so we could watch all the pasta-making magic! We were even treated to two delicious gelato sundaes. I have recommended this place to anyone who would listen. I plan to go back very soon.
author: Courtney G.

description: Decent but not sure the price justifies the taste/portion.
author: Eve H.

description:
This place is the perfect place for lunch. I love the environment because it's not too fancy or anything, it's simple. You can come grab a bite and just do your work.

I come here almost every Wednesday for lunch after my yoga class for the Little Gem Salad. Sometimes I add chicken. The salad has the perfect taste to it. I love the dressing. I've also tried the pasta before and it's pretty good. I just choose not to order pasta to keep a low carb diet haha.

This place is a gem! Keep it up
author: Stephanie L.

description: Terrible experience. I don't really know how this place can call itself a pasta restaurant to be honest and I am not sure how it got 4 stars.... I ordered  the greens salad and my boyfriend ordered the bells pasta with ham and green peas. I have to say that for the price, the quality of the food was below mediocre.  When you treat yourself to a highly caloric meal you usually expect it to be tasty and worth every bite and I have to say that here it was just not the case. If you want to treat yourself o a pasta dish, go to another restaurant in the mission! The service was good which is the only reason why this place would deserve a star but I definitely know that I won't be coming back.
author: Tara J.

description: I had a delicious gluten-free pasta dish, the lumache (snail shells). The focaccia bread was also very tasty and I will definitely be visiting again!
author: Marissa O.

description: The service was amazing, all the ladies working were super sweet and attentive. For the price, my sister and I got great pasta. I will strictly come here for the Vegan pasta plate that was suggested by the lovely lady who attended us in front.
author: Cesilia B.

description:
I went to this restaurant because it is new, near my home, and had incredible ratings.
I love Italian food, having grown up with a mother who cooked Italian frequently, and I was craving pasta. I arrived in an easy-to-please mood.

Ordered up front, sat down. Interesting atmosphere. Staff was friendly enough.

My $16 Strozzapreti baked pasta dish was not only bland and had way too many crunchy breadcrumbs that killed the texture, but it was only about a third of a meal. I was shocked! I looked around - I saw others with bigger pasta dishes and thought, hmm, the good reviews must be due to the other dishes.

Then my girlfriend's Little Gem salad came. $11 for a tiny salad. The yogurt vinaigrette was disgusting. That's a harsh word, I know, but neither of us could eat more than one bite.

We dropped the food off at the front and went nearby for dinner elsewhere. Can't imagine going back.
author: Nicholas H.

description: While at Valencia street walking around my sister and I decided to eat here for a quick bite. This place was so yummy! Had the long noodles with pork and turkey meatballs, we could not stop eating. A must place to eat!
author: Joelle K.

description: Really tasty fast casual Italian food. Price is good for the value. Recommend if you're looking for a quick delicious bite.
author: Brian H.

description:
I've had the pappardelle twice: One great lunch order and once mediocre dinner order. In the latter case the pasta was not coated properly in the sauce so the ribbons stick to each other and clump up, meaning half of the bites are composed of bland, plain pasta. All pasta has the possibility of sticking together/clumping but given the large surface area of the pappardelle ribbons it is extremely apparent and really hampers the dish. In addition my dish came out about ten minutes after the rest of my table (it was a three top). The service is kind of absent for the most part but I understand the restaurant does not employ waitstaff and a host/hostess the same way most traditional restaurants do. Unfortunately this meant there was no opportunity to explain the disappointing pappardelle.

I would recommend ordering pappardelle only when the restaurant is very empty, otherwise the pasta won't get the attention it deserves. I thought the meatballs were a decent value, though. I love fresh pasta and I think the concept is great so I'll probably give them another chance (by ordering a different pasta than pappardelle).
author: Henry T.

description: Such a cute little spot, perfect for a casual date night. Yummy lumache and great wine!
author: Naomi B.

description:
Do yourself a favor and go to this place for an early lunch so you can have a relaxed environment in which you can focus your attention entirely on the f***ing amazing pasta and porchetta. Sit at the counter if you want to see some live pastamaking.

Quality is superb, interior design is on point, and the staff is second to none. Bravo!
author: Paul L.

description: Good food -had a small chicories salad (liked the dressing, which was highly acidic) and turkey meatballs (they were a little dense, sauce was good, but could have used more sweetness/garlic.) All in all, easy and pleasurable.
author: Andrew K.

description:
There is a problem with San Francisco restaurants serving tiny bowls of overpriced pasta.  I was really excited for this place which was supposed to solve this problem.   I have been twice now, and instead of fixing it, it's only perpetuating the problem.

The restaurant is "fast casual" aka counter service.  I actually like the idea of this - less service should mean lower prices, for still great food.  But when the restaurant just charges "normal" prices combined with way too small portions, the entire experience feels like a rip-off.  

My wife and I had:
Snails - in tomato sauce with ricotta $13
Grills - with sausage, broccolini, burrata $16
"Main"- farmers market vegetables $15

To be clear - we deliberately over-ordered, expecting a generous bowl of pasta complemented by some vegetables.  Everything we ordered was undersized by about 30-40%.  Throwing extra noodles in the pot costs ---maybe---an extra dime, but instead they serve what looks visually lacking.  We ate everything and unfortunately left quite hungry.  

The total price with tax and a (small) tip came to $54.  That's not super expensive for a nice dinner out - but this isn't supposed to be that! It's intended to be a fast casual place you can grab a reasonably high quality, quick-ish dinner at a feel good price.  The reality is that it's about as expensive as a normal restaurant.  Being served tiny portions of pasta at a fast-casual restaurant is insulting.

As comparison, the large sized spaghetti w/ tomato at Delfina is $16 - and is legitimately dinner sized.  They even have a small size for $11, which is about what we received at Barzotto.  I'd rather pay $3 extra dollars for an actual dinner at an actual restaurant --- not to mention the difference in quality between the food at Delfina and Barzotto.

Creating a great restaurant shouldn't be that hard.  Simple advice: underprice and overdeliver.  Instead, Barzotto is overpriced and underdelivers.  It's too bad - the potential is there.
author: Daniel W.

description: Nice Italian place specializing in pasta made on site available for package sale plus dining.  You order up front and the food is delivered to the table.  Wine selection is affordable which is nice for a neighborhood place.  The porchetta is worth it and save a little room for the dessert.
author: Kenneth L.

description: Yummy Pastas. Small menu. Order first then be seated. Recommend the Rosè! The community table is a cool place to chat with total strangers :) will definitely be back
author: Kristina M.

description: I've tried this place a couple of times and have left each time disappointed.  I really tried to make this place work.  The food is overpriced for what it is and the to-go portions are quite small.  I will not be back.
author: Adisa K.

description:
Great little place. Great, simple and solid menu. Excellent wine. Pasta had a very flavorful sauce and the salad was fresh and tasty with a good herb dressing.

The decor is modern and well done.

Owners and staff were nice and helpful. The only knock was that my pasta was slightly over-cooked but my wife's was nicely done. Will definitely be back.
author: Benjamin R.

description:
This place is on point. The order at the counter function and central community tables create a low-key, in "grandma's kitchen vibe," but it is so much better , sorry Nana. It's traditional Italian, done very, very well. Small wine list, but every one is delicious. Portions are perfect, staff is friendly, and the design is gorgeous, combining the inviting Italian farm house look with fresh, modern design.

Ultimately, at the price point, it's a place you go on a night out or when you're just too lazy to cook. Also, you can't cook this well, just go there.
author: Nick B.

description:
This is one of those times when the restaurant reviewer of the Chronicle brought attention to a restaurant that would have been lost to me otherwise.  The place is a no frills establishment with some really good food.  Value is the by word here.

You enter and order at the front.  They give you a GPS gizmo of some sort that allows them to find you and deliver your order.  You pick up water from a large tank just beyond the entry.  If this seems a bit awkward, it may well be.  But the food compensates, although it all comes at the same time.  You won't be able to have courses delivered one at a time in a specified order.  

Fazzoletti came with braised beef and mushrooms.  The pasta was a bit overcooked and stuck together.  But there was no arguing with the beef and mushrooms.  

The porchetta was perfection served on a wooden cutting board.  This huge portion of perfectly cooked pork was surrounded by a crispy crust.  And they only mention the condiments that come with the pork on the menu but these were lovely as well.  This was a bargain at sixteen dollars.

It's hard to get a really good meal in San Francisco for under 40 dollars.  You can get it here.
author: David D.

description:
Very interesting concept.  It seems like a sit down restaurant, but you actually order and pay first before you go find yourselves a table.  I guess it's more convenient that way.  However, their service and food plating is just like any restaurant.  

Ordered:
- porchetta board
- little gem salad
- turkey meatballs
- fazzoletti

Porchetta was crispy, but lacked a little flavor and I wish it was warmer.  Little gem salad was creamy but couldn't taste much of the dressing - pretty bland.  Turkey meatballs weren't even hot, and it was really stiff.  Fazzoletti was pretty flavorful, but really oily and wish it had some kind of sauce.  Wines were $10 per glass or $40 a bottle for any wines.  

Overall atmosphere was trendy - perfect for a date night.  I would come back to try the other pastas.  I really liked how we got all the payments out of the way and so you can just enjoy dinner.
author: Nancy S.

description: The menu is not vast, but what they have is really good. Great house-made pastas are the core of the menu. It's casual vibe + perfectly executed food. A well-curated list of beer and wine round out the experience.
author: Scott N.

description: Early Saturday dinner with my son.  The place is where the St Vincent, and before that Heart wine bar used to be, and they've put some nice changes into it.  You order at the counter, then they give you a buzzer and bring your food to you...fast.  We got the bucatini with pancetta and the turkey meatballs.  My son also got an orange juice.   My son said the bucatini was tasty "but had some hard Chewy bits in it."  I would agree, the pasta was a little bit over cooked, but the pancetta was very chewy not crisp, ditto the bread crumbs.  I did not have a problem eating it all however.  The turkey meatballs "were legit" according to my 11 year old.   They were large and moist and tasty, with bits of spinach inside, which made me feel like a better mom.  After dinner we decided to split a "gelato sundae" which was really vanilla soft serve with a squirt of caramel and a scoop of those Callebaut "crispearls" in top.  It was creamy but "kind of tasted like nothing."  The topping ran out almost immediately, and we were left eating vanilla.  So, was it good?  Overall it was kind of expensive for what it was.  $40 to split a small entree, side dish, soft serve and tiny oj in a restaurant that is counter service.  So I'd agree with my son that it was 3.8 stars, but will kick it to four, because there were some nice thoughtful touches in the experience.  Share plates and water you could grab yourself.  Thick napkins and big hooks under the table.  Friendly and fast service, and if you sit at the counter you can watch them making the pasta.  We'll probably go back and try something else and get those meatballs again.
author: Nicole B.

description:
I love the concept of this place.  Love the casual nature of ordering at the counter and then grabbing your seat.  Definitely very modern.  The food was good - I had the special of the day, the roasted chicken raviolini (yum), and my husband had the spaghetti.  We also shared meatballs, which were my favorite thing we ate that night.  The ravioli was delicious but small-ish in portion.  The spaghetti was a little salty for my tastes (although my husband enjoyed it), and the portion was better.  

Overall, not a bad place to grab a light meal.  The prices seem decent at face value by SF standards, but you do have to order a bit to get full so it can still be pricey.
author: Melinda C.

description: Different way of ordering but once you get used to it! No worries. Overall, a great find if you're into fresh made pasta. Loved the pork roast and chimmichuri
author: Eddie I.

description:
I love Barzotto. I send friends and strangers to Barzotto. I'm italian and choosy about my pasta and I'm telling you Barzotto does it so very well. But last night they broke my heart. 

I've probably been there a dozen times or more since they opened.The last two times have been tricky:

On Valentines Day, late after a long day, I stopped just before the kitchen closed to have a glass of wine. They let me know I should order food then if I wanted it - I didn't, I had just been in at a family birthday dinner but was driving so didn't have wine with my meal. So I got my wine, and sat in the window to enjoy it. The windows were open and the lights were on outside, it was misty and romantic. And then the staff started turning off lights, putting chairs on tables, shutting down the place, right around me, and other customers still at tables. I get it, it's almost closing time. But we were all nearly done. 10 minutes wouldn't have hurt and would have been so much friendlier. 

This made it impossible to ignore what happened last night. I stopped for takeout on my way to a resistance postcard writing party. I ordered, and was recommended to the special gnocchi. I paid: $19.44 after taxes and tip. For one dish, to take away. Which was fine, until I opened the lid and realized I was paying about $1.15 per gnocchi. They were delicious. But I was still starving when I finished. It was too expensive. For nearly $20 I should have been full. It's not okay guys. I come from a food family. I understand your margins and rent. But you've got to got to figure this out. 

Thanks for listening.
author: Annie B.

description:
The fresh homemade pastas and the simple yet delicious sauces took me back to Italy.  Our pastas were cooked perfectly.  

I also like the concept of this spot, order at a cashier, get a buzzer, self serve water station and find a seat.  Very laid back but still delivered quality food.  Finally a restaurant to get an authentic pasta dish.  Can't wait to try their other dishes!
author: Jackie L.

description:
We've now been here a few times, and have yet to be disappointed. Barzotto is like fast-casual dining speed with fine dining tastes.

To date, we've had the following dishes (we eat vegetarian and have found the options to be plentiful):
- Cresta di gallo - such good flavors! Lemony, creamy, and a very light kick. I've now gotten this twice and will definitely be back for more.
- Spaghetti with egg - definitely get the egg! Makes it like a vegetarian carbonara.
- Stuffed french toast (brunch offering) - whoaaaaaa. Sweet, but not overwhelmingly so. The fruit/honey flavors were great, and the stuffing inside was marvelous. The toast was also lightly fried like a donut. This was nothing like any french toast we've had, but was amazing nonetheless.
- Gelato - thought this was just okay, but not a huge soft serve fan.

We've also purchased bucatini from them and made our own dish at home. It was, as expected, great. It's nice to have a nearby source of fresh pasta!

Definitely get the egg if you like soft boiled eggs - they are definitely very nicely done.

Everything here has been on point, and we'll definitely be back for more :)
author: Chris M.

description: A group of friends and I decided to try this Italian place out after work on a Tuesday.  We were immediately impressed by the trendy ambience of the restaurant.  You order the food at the front counter, and sit down with your number (Not something I had expected). I shared plates with a friend to taste more of the menu, and we ordered the cockscomb and their special ramen.  I enjoyed the cresta di gallo, the pasta tasted fresh and it was cooked to perfection.  I was not impressed at all with the ramen - I understand that this was a gamble since it is not on the regular menu, but I would not recommend! I didn't taste much flavor, and overall was unsatisfied with it (Don't get me wrong, I was HUNGRY, definitely ate it!!).  I would be willing to try this place again and order another dish!
author: Gina B.

description: So good! Such fresh pasta and inventive roman style sauces! I am seriously in love with how casual yet amazing this place is. GREAT FOOD!
author: Chloé L.

description: A cute and trendy place. The food was amazing. I ordered the flat pasta with stewed beef, a glass of pale ale, and a small salad. The pasta was made and cooked at the right temperature and texture.
author: Jun C.

description: Super cute, smaller, casual italian with home made fresh pasta!!! At a very reasonable price. Highly recommend cabbage and kale salad and half chicken (very tender). The "ribbons" braised beef pasta was to die for ... a MUST HAVE if you visit Barzotto.
author: David C.

description: Mmm.. not outstanding. We were recommended the Campanella and the Italian Ramen- supposedly two of the best items on the menu. We also ordered the focaccia bread for an appetizer. The appetizer was great- the bread was moist and was packed with flavor. When the Campanella came, it looked promising- I really wanted to like it, but my first bite was average. I did like the lemon flavor balanced with the homemade bells, but it missed the mark. There simply was not enough flavor. Next was the Italian Ramen. This was just disappointing- there was no flavor other than the broth. *They should put a note at the bottom: "Tastes like chicken noodle soup." A positive note however, was that the texture of the noodles was excellent. However, I personally feel that both of the two main dishes we ordered were average/below avg. Especially the Italian Ramen. Get this if you have a cold and don't want to miss out on tasting flavor- because there isn't any.
author: Gabby C.

description: Forgot what the pork platter was called....but oh my gosh was it amazing! Perfect amount of crispy pork skin and juicy, succulent meat. You must get this when you go here! The pasta is freshly made everyday and is also amazing! We had the mushroom pasta which was great and nice. It was a bit salty but it was probably since we loaded it up with cheese! Go here and get the pork platter!
author: Queena P.

description: The service was very bad. I went in with my parents to have a nice family diner but it was full. I asked the person at the front if there were any seats available and she said the bar. I asked her if I could see the location and she came off as very strong and told me that if I didn't like it then I didn't have to eat there. I did not under any circumstances come at her in an offensive way, I just asked if I could see the location of the bar. Horrible! I decided to walk away before I put her on blast and gone off on her ‍
author: Bob B.

description:
Great addition to the neighborhood, the mission was in need of a casual and delicious pasta place. Menu is short and simple, which I respect and also they run specials sometimes. 
Open for lunch too! Which I love.
author: Americo P.

description: After hanging out this weekend in the city and going to different restraunts I have to say I was disappointed. It is just ok. Friends recommended it but compared to many other SF restaraunt a it doesn't compare. Go to Berreta or Flour + Water. Am kind of bummed. Was expecting more based on feedback.
author: Claude R.

description:
Great fresh pasta. Great service. Great Wine. it is an old/new Italian trattoria:)

I will be very soon!
author: Nadia K.

description: Dined at Barzotto on Sunday with a friend. I didn't realize you order at a "counter" but still has a restaurant feel which is nice. We started with two glasses of wine, decent size pours for $10 which I can appreciate, and the focaccia bread. For our meals, I scoped out other yelpers orders and pics so I knew what we were getting - started with a small little gems salad (perfect splitting for two), the porchetta and the bells pasta. The salad was so delicious, perfectly dressed and I want to recreate it immediately! The porchetta was so delicious, perfectly cooked and the tangy crispy vegetables on the side paired really well. The pasta, however, was kinda meh. The bells pasta included with braised hen and radish and we both oddly thought it tasted like Thanksgiving dinner. I didn't get a lot of other flavors or textures besides the hen and the pasta. Just because I live far across town not sure if I would initiate another trip but if you're in the neighborhood I think it's a great spot for casual dining with a nice ambience.
author: Aryn C.

description:
DELICIOUS Italian food! A great up and coming trendy pasta bar for a good night out with your friends. The owner is dedicated and greets all the customers. I recommend ordering the Bucatini with a nice glass of wine. 

Get their gelato too!
author: Celine L.

description: Cool, weird, fun, hip, lively place. They make their own pasta. They can sub gluten free pasta for any of their pasta dishes. I think the gluten free pasta is made in similar styles to the pasta they are substituting. Get the half chicken. Maybe consult the menu before you get there, you have to order and pay first.
author: Matt J.

description:
Welp, I've changed my mind - it looks like they've addressed a lot of feedback, and I'm now a big fan of this place! Their portions have improved dramatically, the take out experience is more streamlined, and their rotation of seasonal pasta dishes seems to get more and more delicious each time (my current favorite is their bucatini, with a delicious and creamy sauce made of cherry tomatoes, garlic, and squash). Their salads are also really fresh, and usually with an interesting, creative twist (pickles, yogurt, sesame seeds, and radish in a salad? It works!) 

I also really like the dine-in experience too - it's casual, but in a sort of casually swanky way. I've also enjoyed their wine selections so far.

That said, I still think their pasta dishes are overpriced, but less egregiously now that you get more food. I'm guessing this is in large part because they make their own pasta fresh and in-house, and that labor is expensive, but I think the price is still a bit disappointing given how simple the ingredients in most of their dishes are (e.g. tomatoes, onions, and garlic are not exactly known for being the most expensive of produce). I still find it sort of tragic that they don't serve bread to your table like every other Italian restaurant I've been to, but that may be more a consequence of the "fast casual" style - you only ever get exactly what you ordered. I've also experienced a few off nights, where dishes that usually come out delicious came out not terribly well executed, and also a few dishes that didn't quite work for me (their "Italian Ramen", for instance, I thought was quite bland, and the egg they added was undercooked).

But! Overall, this is one of my go-to restaurants now - nice work Barzotto!
author: M. Q.

description: Came here by accident and I'm glad I did. The pasta here is great and the staff is super nice. The gelato is just whatever but that's not a deal breaker for me.
author: Keanu H.

description: The little shells pasta is covered with sweet tomato sauce and three large dollops of ricotta round out this divine pasta bowl. The cabbage and kale salad was my favorite with a tart vinaigrette that was unexpected and delicious. Major kudos for the chili oil at every table for spicier folks like me. For folks familiar with the Portland, OR dining scene: this restaurant is a second cousin of Luce. Not as charming or chic as Luce but just as welcoming, consistent and flavorful.
author: Sarah L.

description: I love the ambiance of the restaurant and he food is pretty good. The porchetta exceeds our expectation. Little gem salad's dressing is kind of bland. The snails pasta rocks!!
author: Fion S.

description: Three stars for a lovely interior design and a great concept.  We had the Kale & Cabbage salad (excellent) and the gluten-free version of the Cock's Comb Pasta.  I applaud them for making homemade gluten-free pasta, but my wife and I split the dish and we both didn't like the pasta all that much.  They use the same gluten-free pasta for any pasta dish that you order (they only make one type of gluten-free pasta).  Otherwise, the pasta dish was okay for a vegan dish, although a bit heavy on the oil.  We have have much better (albeit, not homemade) gluten-free pasta at Delfina and Vicoletto.
author: Matt and Rita C.

description: Really unfortunate as had been hoping to love this restaurant since its around the corner but food is ok at best (pasta is mushy, porchetta super fatty) and staff is really rude...will not be back.
author: Cece C.

description: This is such an amazing restaurant with awesome service, great food, and modern/hipster ambiance! Honestly the top three important things to have at any restaurant. I recommend trying the ribbons pasta super delicious along with the porchetta, SUPERB! The presentation is nice but the side sauces that come with the porchetta is quite tasty. It definitely gives the meat that extra flavor. For dessert I had the nitro coffee affogato with mint sundae I am a fan of mint and coffee so this definitely was the perfect treat. I wasn't able to get the servers who were so wonderful but I advise you guys getting name tags! I intend on coming back and knowing your names. The only one I was able to get their name was Justin who is one of the managers. He was the cashier super kind and helpful! Keep it up Barzoto great success is coming your way!
author: Jamie M.

description:
When I first read about this place, I thought of my new Seattle obsession: Il Corvo. Order at the counter, pasta focused, reasonably priced wine.  They're open all day, which is nice, but they don't take reservations. However, at 6pm on a Saturday, we were able to get a table without any problems.

Wines: 3 sparkling wines, 3 whites, 3 roses, 3 reds, mostly Italian. We went with one fro Piedmont, which was very light and easy to drink.  All are $40 a bottle.

Food: family style
- Focaccia: nice crust on top, but the highlight was the tomato sauce, which tasted liked it was made from fresh tomatoes
- Farmer's market veggies: not cheap for some vegetables, but it's a beautiful presentation on a nice board with lots of colorful produce. I could have done without the aioli underneath, but I like the fish sauce based sauce (same as the one with the pork)
- Porchetta board: with giardiniera, an applesauce sort of sauce, and the fish sauce based herb sauce in the vegetable board. The pork had a nice crust on it, but the inside was a bit dry. Flavor was good 
- Bucatini: texture wise, this was my favorite. It's like hollowed out spaghetti, so it holds the sauce and has a good bite. The sauce is breadcrumbs, pancetta, and tomato; definitely wipe up any leftover sauce with focaccia 
- Fazzoletti: like super white paparadelle with a braised beef and mushroom sauce, lots of parmesan. This one was nice and hearty
- Cresta di gallo: the most interesting shape (like a cock's comb). It came with cauliflower and a creamy sauce, topped with almonds for crunch. This was an interesting pasta and was a good vegetarian option
- Italian ramen: special of the night. The broth was legit, and it had lots of chicken and a nice soft cooked egg. The pasta was actually very similar to ramen 

Food comes out pretty quickly, and the servers will bus your table for you even though when you order it's just at the counter.  

I'm a sucker for pasta, and I like that it's very no frills.
author: Marilyn H.

description: This review is for the owner, not the food. I was at Barzotto over the weekend with two of my girlfriend's and the owner came over to our table and aggressively introduced himself and offered us free items simply because we were so "nice" and it was a "pleasure" to have us at "his" restaurant. He flirtatiously left his number "in case we ever had anything to say about the business or food." Right. It felt so sleazy and unnecessary! We will not be back! Please respect your customers as just that and not potential women to pick up on.
author: K. S.

description:
Love the design and feel of this new pasta restaurant. It makes great use of a fairly small space by having lots of counter seating and a larger table for groups. There are also several tables along the perimeter of the room, if that's more your vibe. The pastas we had was really flavorful - a bit on the rich side but very good. We also ordered sourdough breadsticks that had a standout marinara dip. Finished dinner off with soft serve ice cream. We each had a different flavor so got to try them all. The caramel and chocolate was the winner

My favorite part was the staff- they were all so helpful and enthusiastic. You could tell they were all invested in making this place a success - I'm so rooting for them!
author: Michelle K.

description: I have passed by this restaurant many times while stopping in at Arizmendi.  Today, I decided to stop in, with a friend, and try it out.  It was just okay in my opinion.  I found nothing special about either pasta we tried.  The snail shells were a bit overcooked.  The accompanying marinara sauce was bland.  I did detect a hint of lemon zest though.  The ricotta seemed to eb added to every dish. The pork meatballs were dull as were the beets. To charge $4 for two small piece is foccacia is just wrong.  I mean, one could get an entire loaf next door for the same price.  I also objected to charge $4 for a San Pellegrino, and then to have only one flavor?  How hard it is to go to Costco and get other flavors?  I asked for a small portion but was given a large for my pasta.  I did not notice until we left that I had been charged so.  Not even in Italy does two pasta dishes and some beets end up costing $43.  I will not return to this place.  While the service was excellent, the prices are ridiculously high.  One is better off getting a slice of pizza next door.  Wish I had stayed away a little longer.  Live and Learn.
author: James S.

description: Nifty spot in the mission that has rich, substantial pasta plates and generous glasses of wine. They only stock ingredients included on their current menu, so be sure to check the website first. I loved my experience here, it was a particularly slow night but given the number of chairs I assume this could get quite busy. They only take square cash up front and give you a number; the food is brought to your table. Some people may have a problem tipping up front, though. Good selection of wine, not so much on beer. The ribbons were exceptional and worth the 17$. The entire menu is actually priced super reasonably. Props to the all-female chef team that was there the night I visited. Great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Amy C.

description: Good place for delicious and quick exciting lunch or dinner of Patras, salads, porcheta, turkey meatballs, roast chicken, wine, beer..... Gelato Sundaes a must taste..... Good people.....
author: Nilo C.

description:
I've been here three times now, and the food is absolutely outstanding. The gluten free pasta is exceptional...the best gluten free pasta I've ever had. Tonight there was a seating snafu and an issue with the timing of our food coming out, but the staff was amazingly responsive, and I really appreciated the lengths they went to make sure we were taken care of. I really recommend this place for 1-2 people. If you have a larger party, you might consider another option or be prepared to wait.

As far as food goes, you can't go wrong. Spaghetti, fazzoletti and porchetta are all favorites!! Highly recommended place.
author: Elizabeth O.

description: I love the pasta here but came for lunch and was super disappointed. I had the porchetta sandwich which was all fat and hardly any meat. I know it's a fatty cut but this was excessive and not cut properly that I basically had a fat sandwich! Then I said I wanted salad so the girl at the counter had me order a side salad. When I got my sandwich to go home and opened the box there was a small salad that came with the sandwich so I didn't need to order the other one. Delicious but waste of money and I should have been told it came with a small side greens. Flavours are there just the delivery was way off on the lunch. Disappointing!
author: lauren B.

description: We stumbled upon this place when we had some time to spare; we're SO GLAD we did! This place was incredibly delicious, the service was friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere was casual & inviting. We got the chicken, homemade pasta, beets, and homemade focaccia bread. We finished every last bit. Will definitely be back again soon! Awesome place to grab a quick bite (no need to be dressed fancy), go on a causal date, or grab a bite with a friend. The homemade pastas are a MUST order; small for personal, large to share.
author: Kayla G.

description: I love this place! I have eaten in and ordered takeout. This place is really close to my boyfriend's work, so we like to meet up and have lunch here. The pastas are great- and the salads are too. The vibe inside the restaurant is also really cool. Will definitely go back!
author: Renee R.

description: Spectacular!  Absolutely delicious homemade pasta in a casual and friendly environment. I'm going back here asap to try everything on their small but well though our menu.
author: Anne B.

description: Very interesting concept that couples deli-style service with high-quality dining. The order-at-the-counter and seat-yourself style typically sets the bar low in my initial opinion, and Barzotto absolutely blew us out of the water. After ordering at the counter and finding a seat for ourselves, my fellow diner and I waited mere minutes for our appetizers (a beautiful though underspoken Little Gem salad and house-made focaccia bread) to arrive, followed in short succession by our pasta (Pappardelle in a savoury slow-roasted beef sauce) and entree (half a roasted chicken accompanied by a sun-dried tomato pesto and assorted house pickles). Each dish was phenomenal and had an endearing quaintness about it, much like home cooking. Despite not being full-service, we were well tended to throughout our dinner. Will definitely be back for more!
author: Jordan W.

description: Such a cute little spot. Just grabbed a glass of Rose and some focaccia and I felt like I was having a little aperitivo in Italy.
author: Karishma S.

description: I had the pleasure of joining Barzotto for their opening and I was thoroughly impressed.  The former St. Vincent space was completely remodeled and has transformed into a beautiful pasta-focused restaurant.  Michelle Minori, their chef, delivered mouth-watering dishes and . . . . can we say self-serve gelato??  Yes, please x 2!!  Looking forward to a neighborhood spot where I can eat delicious food and not break the bank.  Well done, Barzotto!
author: Jordana G.

description: I cannot comprehend how Barzotto has a 4-star rating. The wine, ambiance, and service were good, collectively represented by two stars. I feel badly writing such a terrible review because I am sure wonderful people are trying to make this place work, but the food was so unbelievably disappointing. We ordered the little gem salad, cacio e pepe, and marinara with ricotta pasta. The little gem salad was not made of little gem lettuce. The cacio e pepe (if done right a delicious dish) was not authentic or tasty. The marinara and ricotta pasta was also disappointing; Ragu from the jar has a better flavor. I can only guess that the Barzotto hype has blinded people to its poor quality food. Sorry :(
author: F H.

description: What a beautiful space with a delicious well thought out menu. Outstanding dishes at most reasonable prices, add the fast and friendly service into the fold and you've got pasta perfection .
author: Stephen B.

description: Congratulations on the opening! The space is beautiful, the food is delicious (love the summer salad with radish and pickles), and the service very kind. Welcome to the neighborhood.
author: Susan J.

description: Loved their Fazoletti! My husband and I got the fazoletti pasta, porchetta board, and the little gem salad with a glass of cabernet. I loved the modern vibe here and would definitely come back with friends since the payment system is so convenient. I don't think I'd get the porchetta next time-- it was just too heavy for me. Also, great service from the cashier! She recommended the wine pairing and it was awesome.
author: Jennie Y.

description:
Outstanding.  I came here upon recommendation from my good friend Marielisa who is  a prominent pastry chef and  Barzotto was started by one of her friends. Barzotto is in the former Saint Vincent space. 
Last night, my gf and I came here for dinner. The space is beautiful, modern with high ceilings. I like the order-up-front-take-a-number concept because it feels casual in one sense but the beautiful space makes the experience a little more upscale than say "the grove." Tables are marble, lights dim,  restaurant packed with with wine glasses and conversation buzz. The experience was previously well-thought-out  as the tables are dressed with salt/pepper grinders and chili oil and servers are buzzing around and  were very attentive to diners. They have a simple but decent selection of wine (9, if I recall correctly). We ordered 2 pastas (albeit gluten free) and 2 glasses of wine. Both wine pasta paired well but I have to say the main event, the pasta was exceptional. I haven't had such delicious tasting gluten free pasta since before I developed this allergy. Its not just the fact they had the gf option, or that  the pasta was homemade and shaped such that sauce would adhere to its surface, but it was the flavors that dressed the pasta which took the cake. 
We ordered a pancetta and tomato bucatini and the cauliflower/lemon pasta. 
Bucatini: Legit, you one can taste the sweet pancetta and the hit of rich tomato. They did a great job balancing a little hit of acid to cut the pancetta fat/flavor. 

Cauliflower pasta: excellent, it had clean lemon finish, slight hint of garlic or chive. Creamy but not heavy, great texture with cauliflower and what I think were peanuts instead of breadcrumbs. I know this sounds strange but it was awesome. (they should probably inform diners who order the GF pasta that there are peanuts on top, just a suggestion, it was OK with me).


All in, I'm happy this restaurant has opened up nearby and I will come again. Thank you! Delicious food, great execution and congrats.
author: Reena T.

description: Great place for an inexpensive authentic Italian meal! The cacio e pepe was the best I've had in SF thus far but the strozzapretti was my favorite. The wait staff are friendly and the prices affordable. Pro tip: get the salted caramel/chocolate gelato
author: Shirley H.

description: Cute concept and space. Eh food. Wish you could mix it up for the veggies. Prices are hefty.
author: Gernaut A.

description: Casual. Order at counter. Sit where you like. Fantastic flavors. So fresh, so tasty. Good wine list. Homemade pasta. This one really hit the spot. Fast service. I'm coming back.
author: Omri S.

description: Great pasta, lovely atmosphere. Had the spaghetti, fazoletti, turkey meatballs and salads and everything was so delicious!
author: Sarah G.

description: I went there once when they first opened but went again yesterday and was bitterly disappointed. I had the Cockscomb pasta with cauliflower and it was simply the worst pasta I have ever had.  Totally bland and tasteless if they offered that in Italy they would be arrested.  I should have just sent it back but I guess I am a masochist.  After that I went down to Pi Bar up the street and had a slice of pizza and it was marvelous.
author: David T.

description: Delicious. Super fresh pasta. Good service even though they're pretty busy. Great prices on good wine. Menu selection is small but solid.
author: Janny J.

description: I tried the brunch last weekend and was blown away! Every single item was delicious. I can't wait to go back for dinner!
author: Alison Y.

description: My friend and I ordered Spaghetti and Bucatini for dinner. The food was ok, but suffered an upset stomach after eating the food.
author: Gayathri N.

description: Place is neat and clean. Loved the leather back rests for the long benches. I also like their ordering/paying system as it is very efficient. Went there for lunch and getting a table was easy. I ordered the porchetta with garlic chimichurri and apple chutney and it was delightful. Perfectly cooked. Crunchy skin and juicy moist meat. I also had the homemade spaghetti and I did find the pasta a little chewy for my taste but all in all, still a good plate of creamy pasta. I suggest eating it by itself or with something light as it is rich and creamy. The owner is very nice and the staff were pretty pleasant. Definitely coming back as it is also stumbling distance to my apartment. Gonna have to try all the pastas.
author: duane a.

description: The food is fresh and delicious, large-ish portions and the wine selection is great. I was looking for some outdoor seating with great food and stumbled upon BARZOTTO. They have outdoor seating but I ended sitting at the bar in the front windows. The whole place has a great atmosphere. You order at the counter then they bring you your food. RJ was very helpful with our wine selections.
author: Amanda C.

description: Loved the beet pasta they had. For a self serving place, it was over priced for the quantity.
author: S M.

description:
wow we really love this place.  The staff is so friendly and the food is off the chain.  Whatever that sauce is that comes with the chicken, I want to take a bath in it.  

The pasta is so well done and just yummy.   I had a ridiculous glass of wine for 10 bucks which is completely reasonable.

I look forward to coming back again and again.
author: Slone F.

description: I ordered one of the pasta dishes for dinner. It was alright, although the seasoning was a bit strong for my taste. The portion is quite small, and the quantity of meat was not very generous. Acceptable, but you can get a lot more pasta elsewhere for $15.
author: Bai L.

description: Barzotto has some of the best Italian food I've had this side of the Atlantic. Every dish I've tried has been extremely flavorful and had a beautiful presentation. The atmosphere is casual and I really appreciate the counter service format which lets me get in and out quickly without a fuss. Be sure to try the Porchetta Board or the Porchetta Sandwich!
author: Matthew L.

description: This place is amazing. Yesterday was my first visit. I can safely say that I will be returning once every two weeks.
author: Nicholas D.

description: Amazing neighborhood gem. Outstanding food and never a wait. A must try new spot for brunch or dinner.
author: Rachel P.

description: I entered and while at the counter had a few questions concerning the options.  The gentlemen working the counter was both knowledgable and willing to make suggestions.  I enjoyed the Cockscomb pasta w/cauliflower, garlic, chili, almond, lemon.  The flavors were beautifully balanced and the pasta cooked perfectly; it was easily one of the best bowls of pasta I've ever had.  I was worried the portion of pasta would not be enough and so also I ordered the Porchetta Sando w/calabrian chili aioli, dijon, lettuce, pickles, provolone on sourdough.  *The portion of pasta was very appropriate and I definitely would not order that much food again.  The Porchetta was complete indulgence.  The rich sando was complemented nicely by the side of dressed frisee and pickles.  San Francisco is increasingly difficult to find simply delicious food made with love at a great VALUE but BARZOTTO is doing it right off Valencia in the Mission.  Absolute praise to the Chef.  I am still thinking about the pasta!
author: Dustin B.

description: Food was pretty good, but not mind-blowing like some of the other reviewers describe it (one of the pasta dishes seemed a bit overcooked). BF and I were surprised that you order at a counter.. we were expecting casual but not that casual. The wine prices kind of bugged us. When did $40 for a bottle of wine at a place that takes orders at a counter become reasonable?? I expect $40 to be the low end at mid to high range restaurants, not "fast casual" joints. I've been to many nicer Italian restaurants (with wait service) with fantastic Italian house wines (by bottle or carafe) for much more affordable prices (so I certainly don't believe the 'if you want good wine, you have to pay $40' crap). It's not even about the money (I happily pay that and more at better restaurants), it's just the pretentiousness of it all and the fact San Franciscans have somehow been conned into thinking that this is normal.
author: Vee N.

description:
delicious homemade pasta, beautiful ambiance.  wish the portions were a tad bigger.  perfect for a date.  

minus 1 star because the "gelato" that came out of the soft serve machine was disgusting and had a chemical aftertaste.
author: T Y.

description: Can't say enough good things about this place!  The food is so incredibly flavorful and fresh, and the taste of even simple pasta dishes and salads is uniquely delicious, different in the best way without deviating too much from the basics.  Lots of small details add up to make this an amazing dining experience.  Atmosphere here is fun and a great balance of casual and stylish.
author: Paul M.

description: nice ambiance and the pasta was fresh but dishes did not come out hot and everything was a bit over salted. had that pappardelle with beef and mushroom and focaccia. definitely overrated. dishes looked beautiful but wish they tasted as good as they look.
author: Cat M.

description: Visited Barzotto on a recent visit to San Francisco.  We had a FABULOUS meal.   The pasta is fresh and amazing, the desserts divine and the atmosphere was fun with great music - and great wine!   I highly recommend this restaurant.   The chicories salad was great and very refreshing.  We also had the Ribbons - pasta with braised beef - we fought over the last bite.  The Cock's Comb -  pasta with cauliflower, almond, lemon, etc - was wonderful.   Turkey meatballs were perfectly done.  We were enjoying ourselves so much we ordered two desserts - which were both heavenly - Nitro chocolate with Mint and the Salted Carmel with chocolate.   Perfect!
author: Jamaize S.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! So happy it is right around the corner from us. It is exactly what the neighborhood needed! The food is insane and I love how you order first and then find a table verses waiter/waitress status. The wine lists pairs so well with the pastas. The MEATBALLS... The MEATBALLS! Best ones I have had in SF (I've had my fair share) and the bucatini is nuts. I love this place and can't wait to return!
author: M Q.

description: Nothing beats fresh pasta, and this place does it so well! During my visit I had the Fazoletti and Bucatini. Both were great, I love how the sauce is so flavorful but not overpowering. This place lets the pasta itself be the hero.  I can't wait to try all the other pastas. Plus Marko, the owner is one of the warmest and friendliest person I know!
author: Matthew T.

description: Love this place! Dinner was wonderful, the spaghetti was amazing! Brunch was just as lovely, easy, fast-the food is delicious for great price! Highly recommended :)
author: Allison G.

description: This place is very underwhelming. The service was subpar as we saw a lot of wait staff walking back and forth from the kitchen to the front of the restaurant, but not very observant regarding refills of water, removing of plates, or how they could assist customers, etc.. The food was disappointing. The portions are so small, and the focaccia bread was some of the worst I have had - it was like a dried up piece of bread. I also do not think the idea of "bringing out food as it is ready" works with pasta dishes. For several tables, food was being cleared while other main courses were yet to be served. And the gelato is like custard - I don't know how they can call it gelato. We will not be back. We are used to paying a lot for food in SF, but this place was really overpriced!
author: Jean E.

description: Been only once. I grew up in un Rome where two of the dishes we had come from. The Cacio e Pepe was excellent. It is an astonishingly simple dish that is equally difficult to pull off and takes practice. No butter, no cream - just cheese and hot water and they got the creaminess just right. The Bucatini alla Amatriciana were also very good, maybe a little bit over sauced which is a shame as the pasta itself is what should shine.  Only disappointment was they could have slightly larger portions as one dish was not enough as an only meal. Would have been fine as a "Primo" but that would presume they would have a selection of "secondi" on the Menu and they don't. Will be going back
author: Alex N.

description: Tried Barzotto since it is in our neighborhood and  was pleasantly surprised. Highlights were the non-pasta dishes. The porchetta and the half chicken were really delicious, beautifully presented and the phrase "condiments" in no way did justice to the pickles/lettuce/ grilled lemon/ good sauces that accompanied each of the above. Given today's ever-escalating prices both seemed a very good value. "Winner, winner chicken [and porchetta] dinners." We also ordered a large kale/ cabbage salad was reasonably sized and plenty for three-way sharing. Finally, we ordered the cockscomb pasta which was OK, but undersized for the price, especially in comparison to the other things. Food 41/2 stars and non-pasta value 41/2 stars. What we didn't like: The service model. You order up front either immediately on walking in or by getting back up after being seated. I realize this is the wave of the future, and that it saves on staffing costs but in a restaurant, it  really diminishes the whole experience. Finally all of us hated the lighting. It was so dim in the seating area we could not see the fine print on the menus and could not identify the yummy side bits on the plates. Next time we'll know to bring our camping headlights. There will, however, be a next time. Some of the food is too good to pass up and it is 3 blocks from our apartment.
author: Jim F.

description: Don't be fooled, this is a cafeteria in disguise.  The ambience makes it look like a really nice date spot/modern-style pasta bar, but it is actually more like tech lunch room.  It is not a full service restaurant, which means you order at the cash register and pay first.  Then they give you a Red Lobster style tracking device so they can find you to bring the food.  Everything comes out at once, and the quality is definitely not up to par with the pricing (it is cheaper than other "real" restaurants, but not by much).  The focaccia bread looked like it came out of a box, and tasted that way too.  The pasta quality itself was good, but the sauces taste like something you could make at home with whatever spices you have on hand (we had the Lumache and the Cresta di Gallo).  The screw-top bottle wines are $10 a bottle, and don't expect more descriptors than "light," "medium" or "full bodied" as listed on the menu.  And remember, you'll have to get up and go back to the cash register  during your meal if you want a second glass.  I'm sorry to give a lousy review, but with so many great options for Italian to choose from in SF, this is not one of them.
author: Mt W.
